I say "may dissuade" because this imperfect world is filled with silly things like: "Opinions"and "facts" to me they're different sides of the same coin, instead of sharing my philosophical view with you, I shall proceed with the review: The protagonists' sister has a massive brother complex and the show itself is self-aware of it, some view it as a side-joke, some view it as a turn on and some will be turned off.


It's ever present through out the show so whether you either ignore it, embrace it, power through it or just out-right drop it after the 3 episode rule is up to you, but this isn't kiss x sis or monogatari. that's not the reason why this show has a mean score of 7, maybe it is but that's not the point.


This show has a character nick-named magic-Jesus by it's fans. A common complain is that the character to Overpowered (OP), I ask you, as oppose to solving everything with friendship and hard-earned training?


This show, this show is what happens when James Bond has magic powers and goes to a Japanese high school. Do you watch James Bond for the deep plot? Do you watch James Bond for him to go through character development?  Do you watch James Bond so he can defeat his enemies with friendship and pure willpower?


Hell no.


You watch James Bond because he's a mother-fucking badass that sweeps all the ladies and make his enemies cry.


This is Magic Jesus James Bond: The Anime.


Story? Just another word for "more reasons why Tatsuya is the most badass character ever    conceived" 


Art/Sound? It's by Mad House, nothing can go too wrong.


TL;DR: A loose anime adaptation of the book: "The life and times of Magic Jesus Bond"


007/10 would Onii-Chan again.

I so much wanted to write a Mahouka No Rettousei review for various reasons, mainly positive 
Story 8:The anime centers to the life of two siblings Miyuki and Tatsuya Shiba while being in a prestigous magic school.The girl has a natural charisma while the boy mainly uses his brain and knoweledge to close this gap.The plot also has subrootes and thats 1 him being an undercover and moreover (2) Shiba's status in Tatsuya family.
At this point i would like to comment on the mechanics and characteristics of the magic spells implemented in the anime, they are versatile huge in number and very complicated which personallygave me a great impression since the start of the anime, with other words its quite deep.They dont just throw a fireball or an iceball.There is a ridicously wide range of spells, that can be activated with a very interesting way, Ono Manabu has obviously worked a lot on this.Its not easy to build a magic world and try to adjust/enhance those spells (through an engineer character) and most important to make it beleivable to the audience


Art 9: Outstanding art, from the costumes, the spells through various of items, the battle between students are quite enjoyable and so fun to watch and art plays a major role to that



Sound 10 : What can i say its almost perfect the music during the battles catchy and succesfull, the sound effects of various spells are close to perfect , simply amazing


Character 7: There is so much arguement about Shiba Tatsuya which i really dont understand i disagree with the majority of them, to be specific. Tatsuya is an amazing character he is not the super talent in magic nevertheless he is quite incompetent, he varies from the other MCs with the ridicoulus powers, try hard/shout mentality that after a while he becomes the ''one'' the chosen the superhero.Not even close, actually Tatsuya starts as a Weed*and remains) he is very humble(something i like) modest and straightforward(think i like very much since most of MCs today are cupcakes who never express themselves), and with his efforts he starts to rise in peoples prestige level.

Lets not forget that Tatsuya is considered a magic mind brilliance ,and not because he borned like that but because he owns facilities and he propably has studied a lot. He is one of the rare occations that i dont mind getting all this female attention,and thats because he deserves it, whereas in other animes nowdays MC gets all the attention for simply no reason. I have to agree though that as far as the other characters are concerned , stories are kinda swallow yet but the characters are lovable! The female MC is indeed a bit one sided ,


Enjoyment 8.5: I personally liked a few anime the spring season but Mahouka is sincerly the only anime that kept me excited(and still does) in all its episodes with no exception,The anime has many MANY ''wow' moments and that says a lot



Overall 8: Overall i would normally give it a 8.5 but characters are a main part of every anime so i will give it an 8. I recomment this anime to everyone its great and it will keep u excited all the time.Tatsuya is one of the best characters i've seen , and Mahouka No Rettousei its the most perfect made and well worked example of How world would be if we all had a little bit of magic inside us!

This anime was fantastic. The story line and plot was really good. The animation was also amazing. While many people think that Shiba Tatsuya is over powering I don't really think that's the case. He looks to be strong and really smart among the students of First High but when it comes to members of the ten master clans he's not all that strong. People like Jumonji, Saegusa, and even Erika seemed to be on par in terms of strength with Shiba. None of them really showed their true power in the first season for Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei but you candefinitely tell that they have their own strong abilities and trump cards. Shiba has his own weaknesses and strengths as well. While he's an genius with magical engineering, his practical magic side is terrible even in as a course 2. The only real over powering strength would be his healing magic "Regrowth" but that's the only over powering ability he has and from what I watched and heard, it seems that Shiba's true enemy is his aunt, the head of the Yotsuba clan and she most likely has the means the suppress his Regrowth Magic since she was the one who genetically modified him.

Here goes my first review. There may be a spoiler or two in here. Sorry.
A while ago, an irl friend told me to watch Mahouka when I asked him what I should watch next. I found that it was on Netflix, so I watched it. I went about eight episodes in. I felt I wasn't going to like this around the fifth episode. After the eighth, I put Mahouka on hold. A few weeks had passed, and I considered dropping Mahouka, but my friend asked me how far I'd gotten into it. When I said I was eight episodes in and I had stopped, hetold me to keep going. So I did. I finished Mahouka about four to six months later. Very slowly, watching the show one episode every week or two. I really didn't enjoy it, but I give a damn about my friend, so I finished it for his sake.


Tatsuya was a massively overpowered character who never lost. One-shotting named characters, annihilating all the mooks in seconds, always smarter than every other character, and every time someone is doing a voiceover claiming that something is possible, he manages to do it. It happens so often it's predictable. Don't get me started on how thick his plot armor was. I know he was the main character, but oh boy, he brought himself back to life. How? Magic. Phlebotinum at its finest. He was a bigger male Mary Sue than Kirito from SAO was. He never lost, and it made his character boring.


Don't get me started on how thirsty Miyuki was on Tatsuya's ass. I know brother-sister incest is a common thing in anime, but this case managed to annoy me the most. If you were to take a shot every time she flirted with her brother, you would be dead before the end of the first arc. It bothered me so much that I had the urge to break something every time I heard those words. Those haunting, god damn words...


...


"Onii-sama!"


80% of the episodes include, in chronological order:

Miyuki praising her brother while flirting with him.

Someone claiming Tatsuya isn't all that great.

Miyuki angrily replying to said person.

Tatsuya declaring he will defend his sister's honor through a battle/duel.

Tatsuya humiliating said person through a one-sided fight.

Repeat.


One final thing.

A lot of magic terms were made up in Mahouka. I didn't know what the hell they were, so a character in Mahouka would explain what it was.

After the explanation, I still didn't understand it. Confusing as hell, man.


TL;DR: Overpowered protagonist. Annoying amount of incest subtext. Predictable progression of events. Confusing technological mumbo-jumbo.


5/10.

This anime is a bit controversial especially when it comes to its characters. I have seen most people give it bad reviews although I believe it deserves better. 
TL;DR: I enjoyed the anime and I think the characters are in some way unique.
Story: 5
The world setting is interesting and tries to be more mature than the other anime about magic.
The story itself is broken into arcs. I liked its pacing since it was fast enough not to make me bored but slow enough to engage me into it. The story is well told but a bit rushed nearing the end. I particularly liked that mostof story elements were very logical with the except of couple last episodes which spoiled all the fun. I would put 8 for the story if they did not do that.

I also have to say that I felt like the anime needed more time to show everything in order to enrich enjoyment of watchers. 


Art: 10

The art is great. I mean really great. Everything feels like in place for the world setting. 


Sound: 10

The sound is amazing. It complements the story and probably one of the best I have ever seen in anime. 


Characters: 9

I would say this is the most controversial point in this anime. 

There is a lot of people who hate the way Tatsuya is overpowered and what he does. This is something you either like or hate. Not much to say here. 

What I would like to point out is the way characters behave and live through the story. This is a strong point of this anime. Most of the characters who get enough screen time feel very natural and realistic. They are given some set of characteristics and they go through the story logically according to their personalities.

I find the siblings really great.


Enjoyment: 7

I really enjoyed Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei. Although it could have been better.

I felt like the anime should have been longer to really develop the story. 

The story is unfortunately the weakest point of it. As I said the anime was ruined by 2-3 last episodes. These episodes just took away all the realistic approach to the whole series.



More details on characters and why I liked them. Might contain SPOILERS but I will try to avoid them:


I would say I have liked all the characters maybe with the exception of school psychologist. 

There can be written a lot about every character but I will write only about main cast. I have to say that probably what I saw in Shiba siblings is what I wanted to see or how I interpreted it.


Both Shiba siblings are victims of their family. I would really like to see the continuation of these series to get more details of what and how it happened.


Tatsuya:

The way he is fond of his sister is very interesting and at the moment of writing I cannot recall any other character who was similar to him in this way. The love (well, if you can call it so) to Miyuki is probably the only emotions set he feels and it is interesting to see to what it might lead when a human is only capable of one emotions set. 

I would say that Tatsuya is generally a good person. This is another interesting point of his character when you see someone good but emotionless. 

Some have said that he is like Mike Tyson who beats children in kindergarden with a smile but I would rather say that he is like an adult who, because of certain circumstances, must protect a child in kindergarden. He does not enjoy this superior position. He does not like to beat other students in order to protect his sister or her wishes. He seems to do not like to be in the school but he loves Miyuki and will do anything to please her.


Miyuki:

Well behaved on public (mostly) but in a charming way spoiled and a bit wicked girl when it comes to her brother. I find her very cute and realistic female character. Her love to her brother sometimes goes on the edge of sanity.

Let me make this clear before I begin: I rate things with a very heavy weighting towards enjoyment. This is why I rated Mahouka a 10 overall, despite it's only decent characters and storyline. With that said, this anime is definitely not for everyone.
I honestly have trouble seeing what the disconnect is between Mahouka's reviews (an average of roughly a strong 3) and it's ratings (a solid 7.5ish). Either some people are too critical, or far too many people don't appreciate the time, effort, and dedication that goes into building a world as complex and detailed as this one.
Story - 7
Mahouka's story is fairly generic,but well done overall. Typical high school setting, nearly deteriorating into a harem anime at some points, but somehow Madhouse managed to make the issues feel a lot more important than most similar shows can pull off. Be prepared, though, for exposition. Lots of it. This show will have a 2 minute fight, then spend 10 minutes explaining what happened, over and over again. If you don't mind trawling through an hour's worth of information condensed into a few minutes on a regular basis, though, there's plenty of interesting nuances that really make the world come to life.


Art - 10

Mahouka is an absolutely beautiful show. The character designs are a bit more subtle than most shows, giving it a better sense of realism. There are only a couple mild cases of protagonist hair, and even those wouldn't be impossible naturally. The animation is smooth and fluid, especially during fight scenes, drawing you into the action like few shows can. Even the environments are well done, fitting the show's atmosphere to a T and never getting out of sync with the characters or action going on in front of it.


Sound - 8

Two good but not great OPs, one awesome and one decent ending, and great SFX and voice acting the entire way through. Could be better, but not by a ton.


Characters -  6

Fairly generic and OP, but not altogether bad. A ridiculously overpowered protagonist, a borderline incestuous sister, and an entourage of supporting characters with good personalities but minimal backstory comprise most of the cast. However, unlike many shows that fall along the same lines, there is not a single named character in the show that's useless. Not. One. Every character is shown at some point doing something completely, unbelievably, incredibly badass, and every character serves their purpose in a big way over the course of the show, with not a single one falling by the wayside in unfulfilled anonymity. The show gives the sense that, without the godlike protagonist stealing the show, the characters would still find some way to win, even if it was one on 1000.


And now for a couple categories that you don't really see much, because I don't think reviewing Mahouka without them would be fair.


Worldbuilding - 10

Good world building, in my opinion, always falls at either end of a spectrum. There are vast, expansive worlds like Star Wars or Lord of the Rings that give the sense that there is truly no end to the possibilities of the world, and there are smaller worlds like Harry Potter that are fleshed out down to the last tiny detail. Mahouka falls firmly under the latter. A dedicated viewer can take the huge, dense amount of information that the show throws at you and tear it apart piece by piece to uncover the very foundations of Mahouka's world, and not a crack is left unfilled. The sheer detail with which the world is constructed gives it an immense sense of realism, especially for science fiction - you get the feeling that, while there is certainly more to be discovered, the rules of the world have been well defined to the point it becomes almost real.


Magic System - 10

There is no getting around the fact that Mahouka is a magic anime, even with it's tech elements. Personally, there is not much I love more than a well-done magic system, and Mahouka fits the bill perfectly. Far too many stories make magic this arcane, incomprehensible thing with only the barest of rules if any (looking at you, Fairy Tail). Mahouka does not. It's magic system is not only unique and innovative in it's technological ties, but is thought out and defined down to the last tiny little detail, much as the world itself is. You will not find characters in Mahouka breaking the rules of the world - even when they do things that were thought to be impossible, there is always an explanation to come of exactly how they found the loophole in the system or rethought the problem and came out victorious.


Tech Talk - 8

Being not only a magic anime, but also a tech anime, Mahouka inevitably fell into the trap of meaningless tech babble a few times. However, this didn't happen nearly as much as I expected going in, or as much as other reviewers seem to think. 95% of the time, what other reviewers have construed as tech babble actually fits the world, and makes sense once you dig in a little bit and uncover the structure of the system. This applies to both magic-related and more mundane talk; there simply isn't much actually meaningless tech babble to go around. It's all very well thought out and planned, so that even when they're speaking what would be gibberish with real world concepts, it actually fits and explains the system in a very coherent way.


And finally...


Enjoyment - 10

I absolutely loved Mahouka. End of story. I love a show that can pull off such a complex, detailed world as this without any glaring holes. Simply wrapping my mind around the magic system was enjoyable for me, and really isn't that hard as long as you pay attention to the "meaningless" tech babble - like I said, almost none of it is actually meaningless. The beautiful art, well-scripted fight scenes, and layer of realistic technological detail behind it all amounts to possibly one of my favorite action-centered shows yet.


Overall - 10

As I said, I rate with a heavy weighting towards enjoyment. Mahouka, in my opinion, probably deserves an 8 if you take that out of the equation. The show is definitely not for everyone, with it's over-the-top exposition, incestuous undertones, and simply the sheer level of detail you need to grasp to fully understand and enjoy the show. However, if you enjoy or can put those aside, it is definitely worth the watch, and I highly recommend it. All in all, I will definitely be looking forward to the movie scheduled for July 2017.

I'll attempt to do my best to not reveal any spoilers but that may be difficult  in a review where it's really critical to analyze a confusing story that contained an inordinate number of characters.
I'll preface this by saying that I still consider myself a relative novice in the anime community as I've really only been watching anime outside of the mainstream for the past year or so. That being said, I think I probably have seen enough to accurately judge basic elements of a show at this point. Anyway, like most shows I see these days, I didn't know much about this showbeyond the generic description provided by Netflix that this was a show about a magical high school. While this topic isn't necessarily unique at this point, it stilled piqued my interest and I don't mind school drama or magic shows.


As depicted in the prologue of this show, the premise was that in the 21st century, the population of Earth was ravaged by war due to an inadequate and depleting supply of natural resources. This Third World War was ended and the planet saved by magicians but the population dropped to 3 billion and the world was left to recover from the remnants.


Problems have already crept up as early as this simple expository setting. During this story, we are told that nuclear weapons are never used. While I know that's not a serious issue and I can suspend my belief for something like this but this show constantly fails to provide basic background information. In fact Mahouka did a very poor job at world building and even after seeing the entire anime, I really don't understand this futuristic Earth. Some necessary elements that are critical for the viewer at this point might be the basic structure of the world order, where did the magicians even come from, and how does this system of magic even work? For a show whose foundation is built on a society of magic, I never fully grasped the magical system or the role of magicians within society. Now there are many shows that will present a simplistic view of magic that don't quite require any complex explanation of how things exactly work  like Fairy Tail or such. We're presented with the fact that magic exists throughout the world and individuals can learn to master and specialize in it. Mahouka does go into detail when describing how spells work but since as a viewer I never was given a rudimentary and understandable explanation of how the magic system works, there is no way I can comprehend a discussion over the course of a few minutes on the intricacies of the theories behind a particular spell. For instance, in one scene, a spell is described as the user generating three magical areas in the shape of three dimensional squares with each square being within each other and each vertex containing another magical circle with a six meter diameter or radius) which can be detonated by the user pulling the trigger on a CAD. It's pointless to have so many technical discussions like so filled with obscure jargon that is nonsensical to the viewer. I typically don't watch shows expecting to be bombarded with incomprehensible scientific facts that might be seen in high level physics courses.


Enough of that, so after the prologue I assumed that this show was likely going to be about newly developed high school academies devoted to magic preparing their students for a world that was basically in a magical arms race. Apparently I was wrong. I can't really tell you what this show was about. Mahouka seemed to want to have every possible element in it to the point where the story was largely incoherent. The story was broken into three arcs that were fairly distinct from each other but seemed to bounce from themes of discrimination, manipulation, terrorism, athletic competition, theoretical magic, love, etc. etc. This was a mix of James Bond goes to Hogwarts where he reveals himself to be Superman who has discovered all the Dragon Balls to start a harem where he competes in the Tri-Wizard Competition and wins the Nobel prize for science and then wins the heart of his imouto...wait...he probably won the heart of his sister before the show started. ONII-SAMA!


The first arc focused on the fact that the high school had a discriminatory practice in place in which students who scored highly on their exams were put on the Course 1 track and called Blooms and those who didn't score as high were put on the Course 2 track and called Weeds. This system of discrimination made absolutely no sense because this high school was apparently the most prestigious high school in all of Japan and only seemed to accept the best students. Also the discrimination seemed to be something that was largely instituted by the students themselves so I'm not sure how this system became institutionalized if it wasn't done by the administration. Also, the majority of characters we are introduced to are either very sympathetic to Course 2 students (like everyone on the Student Council, what a coincidence) or Course 2 students themselves. Even though you think the first arc is going to focus and resolve this issue,  it doesn't really. Instead they have a polite discussion about how discrimination is bad but Course 2 students are in fact just lazy moochers who don't really deserve better treatment anyway...also they should give up magic if they can't cut it. There are other issues that do get resolved that are a bit bizarre in and of themselves but I've rambled for long enough.


I guess I won't go any further with the story except to state one last point and that is that I never understood  what the antagonists' motives were during this entire show. They were largely just there for plot purposes.


On to the characters and there were so many of them. At times I thought I was watching one of the later seasons of Durarara except this time not only could I not recall what everyone's name was, half the characters looked so similar I had an incredibly difficult time telling them apart. Besides so many characters looking similar (there were a number of males with short mouse brown hair and then a number of females with mouse brown hair who I could not differentiate between for large portions of the show), many characters had extremely similar names. Now as a native English speaker, I already have difficulties remembering Japanese names especially considering the Japanese cultural usage of primarily using one's surname instead of first name. Anyway, as for similar names, there was a Miyuki, a Mayumi, a Masaki, a Mizuki, a Mitsui, and a Mibu. At least they referred to one character as George, I could remember that one. Anyway, even after 26 episodes, Mahouka rarely spent any time actually developing the characters. I never learned much about the backgrounds of any of the characters nor do many of them have much of a personality beyond a stereotype or caricature meant for the plot. Characters are critical for any good story but the characters in Mahouka are just quantity with absolutely no quality. I don't know anyone's underlying motivations, some of the characters' actions make no sense at all, and because of this I can't emotionally connect with anyone on any level in this show.


I will go over the two main and most controversial characters in this show, the siblings Tatsuya and Miyuki Shiba. Now Tatsuya is a very typical overpowered character...maybe not typical in that he is perfect in everything and that's not true most of the time. Ironically, you usually only see one overpowered character but Miyuki is also overpowered. Tatsuya starts high school as a Course 2 student but we quickly learn that he is probably the most gifted magician in the entire world. The reason we're given for him being put in a lower tiered track in high school is that he apparently can't use "practical" magic at a great level which was part of the high school exam. Even though, he just happens to be a genius who not only can read spells as they are casted, he can invent new magical weaponry and devices, prove magical theories, disable spells, visualize through sensory magic his surroundings and individuals, make people combust, disable weapons, cast some of the highest level spells, not die, bring others back to life, program CADs, and have all the girls fall in love with him while being oblivious. He's also pretty emotionless throughout the show which is never really explained. Miyuki, on the other hand, has great capacity for normal magic and can cast some of the most devastating spells in the show but she doesn't quite have the sheer invincibility of her brother. She does have this strange, unexplained, romantic, and incestuous love for her brother which is also never explained. She even incapacitates Tatsuya at one point because he doesn't acknowledge her as a woman when she is half naked. Beyond that she often freezes the surrounding environment and loses control of her magic when she thinks Tatsuya is getting too close to other women, she nearly kisses him in one scene and then runs to her room and cries when she got caught, she rolls around half naked in her bed blushing after Tatsuya wipes her tears away, and she blushes every time Tatsuya says nice things to her. Just a normal brother and sister relationship. Miyuki went from being weird to annoying to creepy to being yandere for me. I did not like either of the main characters. If a character is going to be invincible then you need to play off that. You could go the One Punch Man route and make it a comedic parody or you could make the show about overcoming obstacles outside of sheer strength. These characters are just too perfect and while people want themselves to be perfect, watching perfection is boring.


Mahouka apparently did not fully cover the light novels and I'm not sure if there are any plans for further seasons, though I'm not sure if it would be worth it to watch Tatsuya walk through another 26 episodes unchallenged. It seems the light novels do provide some explanations past where the anime has ended but I still can't comprehend the light novels resolving all the various flaws in this story. Character development needs to come earlier and can't wait until volume 8 or so for critical background. Also no story can sustain this many characters with absolutely no development. But I can't imagine that the main characters could possibly be any better in the light novels. Tatsuya is presented as invincible. I doubt that was necessarily the animation studio's choice so I assume that comes from the light novels. Also the story is from the light novels so if the plot was nonsensical in the show, it's probably not any better there.


I won't judge anyone who enjoyed this show or disagrees with my opinion. The ability to enjoy anything is always an incredible thing and anyone who enjoys something (as long as it's not sick and twisted or hurtful to others) has the right to it. Everyone also has the right to their own opinions because we all have different tastes. I'm sure many people hate my favorite shows but that's life for ya.

skimming through reviews of this series, i could not hold back from writing one myself.
because i read the light novel of this series, i may be biased. however, i do not agree with negative reviews i am reading on this series.
in my opinion, this series is a must seen for those who are tired of watching lame protagonist who tries to be funny, is a senti at the same time, and gets nakama power ups in every battle.
STORY
if you ask me only about light novel, i would rate the story 10/10. it is simply outstanding. author did a brilliant job in creating a world witha well thought out system of magic that is also complex, detailed, and remains consistent through out. you will have hard time finding holes in the system of magic. this, however, was achieved through tons and tons of description.


because anime can not incorporate all the description, for obvious reasons, story does not seem as brilliant as it was originally intended. it is still a lot better than many others, so i rate the story 9/10.


ART


art is pretty good, but not as good as this series deserves. the thing this series lacks in the art department is creativity, which could be seen in shingeki no kyojin and no game no life. so i would rate the art this series 8/10.


SOUND


again, not bad, but not as good as this series deserves. battles and highlight moments could have been more thrilling and exciting, if background music was better. the thing this series lacks is the goosebump moments. so i rate the sound of this series 8/10.


CHARACTER


most of the reviews i read seem to not be a fan of overpowered protagonist. well, i guess they are still inclined to traditional shounen series.


like many have pointed out, protagonist is OP. however, i do not find it a negative point of the series because i needed a change from nakama power ups or training before every battle to acquire new abilities.


only thing i am not a fan of in this series is the hint of incest. still, i rate characters 9/10.


ENJOYMENT


8/10 only due to art and sound


OVERALL


i would rate this series 8 only due to art and sound. if music and art style were better, like shingeki no kyojin and no game no life, i would have rated it 9/10, if not more.

This is definitely an anime everyone should watch. The philosophic dialogue by the main character was occasionally very enlightening and an eye-opener. It was a stunning departure from the cliché I have come to expect from media in general. 
 How many shows have I watched where the plot is always exactly the same? In a normal anime, we know the main character is going to have a huge emotional breakdown and emerge from it with superpowers that defy logic and use them to thwart the supervillan, despite being weaker to begin with. Ok, that's cool a few times, but the more times yousee it over and over, the more you get tired of the predictability of it.


 This is not the plotline in Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei. The plot was utterly unpredictable, at least until the "thesis arc" brought forth a bit of deja vu, but it still managed to pull more surprises out from under the hat. 


 Some very important themes were spoken here and I feel like this anime was much closer to reality than the emotional garbage spewed out by most others. The characters felt real.


 This show will give your imagination a needed workout.

After completing 26 episodes of this anime, I find it amazingly enjoyable. I can see many people loves it, while others dislike it, and I guess I understand why: The main female protagonist has some god-like power.
Story: The story circles around two siblings, Miyuki and Tatsuya, and their friends at First High School. The two have to overcome difficulties from their family, terrorists, secret organizations... Despite lacking some breakthrough situations, the story is very good. Although I'd like to see more Miyuki in action.
Art: The art is quite acceptable to me. I have no complain about the anime art.
Sound: "Rising Hope" is awesome. It hasto be one of the top anime theme song this year.\n
Character: This has to be one of the most debatable subject. The main male protagonist, Tatsuya, is very very very strong. Seriously, he can create a nuclear-like explosion and regenerate himself as well as others. His friends are no where near his level. However, his sister, who is also not as powerful as him, is very talented and has insane abilities, which unfortunately are not revealed in this season yet.\n
Enjoyment: I personally find this anime interesting, while many people don't due to the power of one character.\n
Overall: I give this anime 10, and many people will disagree. I'm good with that. Everybody has their opinions. I find this anime fun, exciting and enjoyable, so there is no reason for it not to get 10 from me.

It started off good, with an excellent premise and setting. I liked the entire cast (except Miyuki) at first, and I liked the idea of the Bloom/Weed prejudice, even if it's nothing new. But as the show went on and conflicts arose, it felt like I was watching Rhett and Link's "Rub Some Bacon On It" given anime from, with Tatsuya Shiba being the bacon, and with all the humor removed. (Saying "Rub Some Tatsuya On It" in response to my friends' problems has become an inside joke among us.) Every time a conflict arose, precious Onii-Sama would always erupt on the scene and solveit in a matter of seconds. I liked the idea of a talented Weed closing the gap between the classes, but as the show went on, I felt like it was just a half-baked attempt to make him seem sympathetic or flawed. To top it all off is the fact that he's so humble about it. I'd like it if he was a conceited, smug jerk about it better than this bland, uninteresting cardboard cutout.


I hate Miyuki just as much, but for mostly different reasons. True, there was the whole "that move is difficult to pull off even for experts" thing, and the "she's so overwhelmingly powerful that she made the EMOTIONLESS GIRL, the RUNNER-UP in the competition, CRY" thing, which are bad enough, but mostly, it's her creepy incestuous obsession. I'd take Suguha's love for Kirito over this any day. It was still an eye-roller, but it didn't feel nearly as... revolting as Miyuki's. I'm usually a huge sucker for protective older brothers and cute younger sisters, but this pair honestly makes me want to retch every time they make eye contact. Miyuki is one of the most one-dimensional characters I've ever seen in an anime. Everything about her is just "Onii-sama" this and "Onii-sama" that, with no hint of any motivation beyond making life easier for her precious Onii-sama.


Then there's the rest of the characters. First off is Takeaki Kirihara, probably the only character I started off not liking, then liked more as the series went on. After episode 5, he becomes a sympathetic, capable and pretty cool guy, but his transformation, to put it bluntly, was bull. He attacked a girl with lethal magic and force under the pretext of showing her that magic would forever be superior to non-magic, then later states that he did it to bring out the best in the girl he attacked. His excuse is pathetic and tacked-on, resembling something I wrote when I was making my own manga at the ripe old age of 13. And even THEN, I realized what a bad move that was. He would have been one of my favorite characters if he had just been introduced for the first time in episode 6, but as he stands now, I only like him a bit.


Pretty much the entirety of the female cast is uniform in my eyes. I liked them a lot to begin with, each with their own charms and quirks, even if a lot of them were just re-applications of old Tropes (Rei expies are always good, though). As the story went along, however, almost every one of them followed Miss Yandere in falling in love with precious, wonderful, perfect Onii-sama. Being near that man is enough to make any female cast member blush. EVEN THE EMOTIONLESS SHIZUKU! THAT'S RIGHT, EVEN THE REI AYANAMI CLONE! Her and Mibu falling for him were the last straw for me. The whole reason why people love Rei clones is entirely because of their stoicism! Having one blush and smile when alone in a room with the perfect main character whom everybody loves just shows how blatantly the creators don't understand the archetype! If a character that previously never uttered sentences longer than six words in length is suddenly talking in full paragraphs to praise almighty Onii-sama, then there is clearly something wrong with this picture! Honestly, at that point I was convinced they were just doing it on purpose.


The male cast members, at least, are alright, because they can't be attracted to him. Still, all of them (except Katsuto Jyumonji and people that hate sweet, precious Onii-sama) seem to rely on him to solve every single problem. I would go so far as to say that the majority of all of the characters exist SOLELY to provide means by which Onii-sama can prove that he is the very best like no one ever was.


However, amid this sea of Onii-sama-worshipping zombies (and I'm not talking about the fanbase) there are still a few good characters. Mizuki Shibata and Erika Chiba are so far, two of the maybe three female characters that have gotten any focus to not show any romantic interest in him. Erika is very much a standard tsundere, but I think both of these girls have potential, and I wish they could have been the female leads instead of Miyuki. Katsuto Jumonji is probably my favorite character overall, as he's powerful but holds back quietly, leading well but not stealing the show like someone else. His quiet nature makes every time he opens his mouth to give a command its own small moment of awesome. In my opinion, anime could use many more characters like him. (To be fair, he reminds me of Onua, one of my favorite characters of all time, so I'm biased here.)


Looking at the male characters unobjectively, Mikihiko Yoshida is probably the best. His magic is genuinely difficult to use but has much potential, is much more mysterious than the other forms, and he as a character has seen more growth than any other by the point I stopped at. I think he could have had IMMENSE potential as a main character, and I would certainly watch a spin-off show about only him.


Moving on, in the inter-school competition, their student council seems so confident of their superiority that they're dissatisfied just having someone with half as many points as them. On top of that, it seems like only the girls get any focus while the guys are apparently only performing moderately well, which shows a thinly concealed (if even that) excuse to just focus on the pretty girls. Oh, except for Tatsuya, of course.


To reiterate: Why don't we see any of the male competitors? Because the viewers want to watch their waifus dominate. Why are the male competitors doing so poorly? Because we need Tatsuya to fix everything so that the girls make up for them.


At this point, the show is unwatchable for anyone with common story writing sense and self-respect. No dedicated author who knows his stuff could watch this show and not come out of it feeling dirty by the time they've gotten to around episode 9.


As an added thought, a lot of people praise the ingenuity of the magic system in the show, but I feel it is over-hyped, and not really all that spectacular. It's original, and I by no means dislike it, but I feel like people put this aspect up on a pedestal, and some even give the show a perfect rating purely due to it, which, with an anime this horrible, is a crime of the highest degree.


A part of its mediocrity is the fact that, to this point, the magic battles are hardly spectacular. You don't get the sort of trading of magic attacks that could be found in, say, Fullmetal Alchemist or Fairy Tail. I wouldn't attribute this purely to the magic itself, of course, it's simply that the most spectacular aspect of the battles is the physical part, while the magic either just adds a sparkly, mystical side to it, or otherwise provides a simple and easy way to just end the battle before a real exchange of blows has begun. This aspect alone, I would rate 7/10 at MOST. Intriguing, but nothing to write home about.


And now we come to Suzaku. Or whatever his name was. I liked this guy, and even though I didn't think for a minute that he could pull it off, I still hoped he could pull Onii-sama down a notch. True to my expectations, he failed, despite getting close. Some might argue it was good that he technically beat Tatsuya, but the moment was so short it took away all of the potential. Tatsuya immediately heals himself and unleashes a sonic boom, ending the match. I lost interest after the student council finished discussing it and stopped watching there entiely, deciding to pretend Tatsuya stayed dead and everyone lived happily ever after.


"But it gets better later!" some say. To which I say "Later is TOO late!" If you want a good series, you need to start off well and keep it there, something this show failed spectacularly at. Onii-sama sucks any sense of danger out of the story, and Miyuki layers a load of revolting incest on top of the show's desiccated remains, resulting in a mess of utter garbage. Now, I am by no means an expert, and the pool of anime I've watched is shallow, but as far as my experience goes, this anime is the worst I have ever watched, and I would give it a solid 0, it is just that bad.


There IS one way to salvage the show, though. First off, kill Tatsuya, then make Miyuki commit suicide. With the two of them gone, the rest of the characters should become capable of standing up without Tatsuya designing new legs for them. Of course, we all know this is never going to happen, so with that I'll end my rant here by saying this show is a cesspool of everything that can go wrong with a good idea, and that I can't understand how anybody could possibly give it a rating of more than 5/10 after watching past episode nine.

Now I'll admit this show isn't for everyone. However, I'll try to explain why I enjoyed it and yes I'm hoping for a second season. First of all the characters: 
Tatsuya is by far a favorite of mine. I think he's for a certain type of audience however. If you enjoy the overpowered, incredibly intelligent type who you kinda already know will win then he's your type (Sherlock holmes is an example of this type). As someone who goes to a school for the "gifted" ( yeah that's what they call it, it's stupid) where 9 year olds are in calculus I enjoyed the waythey portrayed the emotional gap that many intelligent people face. Everything needs to be rational meaning that emotions are often ignored or thought of as useless. Tatsuya was very good at portraying this in a similar way to how I encounter it in my everyday life. \n
I also enjoyed the way they didn't create an atmosphere where it was okay to think that pure equality was possible. The way the show portrayed how every person has both strengths and weaknesses and therefore nothing can be entirely equal was wonderful. I'm sick of shows sympathizing with characters who believe that simply because they lack in one area that they're useless. (Spoilers) when one of the characters fought for equal rights for less magically talented people at a magic high school I was very glad that Tatsuya pointed out the irrationality of that and the way people simply complain about inequality yet never propose a solution. At my school I am what you would call a "weed" among nine year old geniuses I expect to be treated as lesser. It only makes sense as its a school and therefore being smart is highly valued, just as at this magic school being magical is highly valued. \n
Next, the long magic explanations. I can understand where this can get boring but as I'm highly interested in science getting to see the mechanics of the world and its magic was amazing. I liked getting to work through the ideas and think about their applications. I often get frustrated when these things are not explained so this show was perfect for me in that respect. The fact that the writers took the time to think about the mechanics of the world in such depth was very impressive. \n
On the down side, I found miyuki's obsession with her brother rather odd, along with the way the characters constantly pointed out the immodesty of the girls' outfits while the camera provided lingering boob shots. But hey animes fan service so I didn't really expect anything different.

So here's another one of my short reviews. The animation in this production is fantastic, bright vivid colours that catch your eye from the very start. If you liked Sword Art Online, you'll probably like this. People who hated SAO, I'd recommend to stay away. The main character is extremely OP and is incapable of dying. Besides that, I find the characters in this anime somewhat enjoyable, the story line seemed a bit clouded at first, however as the anime progressed I felt there was more momentum. Hopefully there will be a second season to elaborate on the gaps in the plot but in allhonesty I was so caught up in the moment I didn't really care. If you take this anime for it's positives rather than it's negatives you'll find it's a pretty down right awesome experience.\n\n
Overall, this anime was enjoyable for me, I found myself watching several episodes before looking at my watch and realising it was 3AM. If you want to watch an anime that has to do with pretty girls, school life, magic and a pretty decent storyline without having boobs shoved in your face every 2nd episode. Then this is the one for you. If you're looking for something with an in depth storyline and plot twists.. then it really isn't. Unless they start revealing some of our answered questions in the 2nd season, I will wait with anticipation. Until then, this anime gets a thumbs up from me!

After watching this series, I was left with a sense of profound disappointment. I loved the premise and the setting of the show which deals with a tightly integrated science and magic fusion. Also the concept of the quiet, loner boy who was the 'weakest' but secretly most overpowered character is an oft repeated and well loved theme in all forms of media. Yet at the end, I was left feeling that this series could have been so much more.
A good story has to have 2 elements - relatable characters and suspense/tension.
Unfortunately Mahouka does it's best to keep it's audience at arm's length while failingto provide any suspense or tension as the story progresses. I have nothing against characters progressing to overpoweredness or having secret weapons, yet there should always be a sense of growth through conflict and that there is something at stake or a cost to be paid.


I won't go into spoilers but suffice to say that there is no sense of development in the relationships between Tatsuya, his sister nor his classmates/teammates. As you watch you wonder, what's wrong with the characters? Do they not have feelings? There is a vague sense of unease that the only relationship is a semi incestous one between the siblings but no sense of romantic tension with other characters.


Also, without the risk of defeat or loss, the story fails to engage and excite the viewers. The fight scenes while well drawn, do not really convey any emotional impact. 


In conclusion, this is a very disappointing series. For a truly rollicking and exciting ride, I would recommend Code Geass - that is a series with true twists, turns, highs and lows. As it is, Mahouka started off with promise but ultimately faded without a whimper.

I can start off by saying  that this anime is not for everyone. If you're looking for intense action throughout the series, you're not gonna get it in Mahouka Koukou.  However, if you are open minded and you can accept the fact that the series is very complex when comes to its lore and you appreciate how much effort the author has given to expanding a mere book, then you'll probably love this series. Mahouka Koukou has lots of dialogue and that is not a bad thing in my honest opinion. On the contrary, few anime series barely gives you enough story andinformation and makes the story feel hollow and unfinished with many plot holes. Many for some reason find the excess of the plot to be unattractive, but I find it to be Mahoukas strongest point. Here is my review of Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei:


Story: The story is very straightforward and intense at times. While the whole incest topic is taboo among many viewers, I actually kinda supported the ship. It didn't feel too disgusting, not even the scenes where it was taken to another level. Yes, Miyuki might be one of the biggest bro-con in anime history but I felt like the incest in this anime made the series better. I am not quite sure why but somehow, the series got a trademark which of course makes it stand out. It dares to go beyond the norms that are accepted but not too greatly as to gross out the audience. Another plot thing that has been done before that I enjoyed was Tatsuya's background. He is unable to feel any strong emotions. The only emotion he has left is his protection and love for his younger sister. Tatsuya might seem weak, but Mahouka actually shows off his strongest points. Tatsuya is a bad ass! The other protagonist is Shiba Miyuki, the ice queen and Tatsuya's younger sister. She is strong, beautiful, independent and perfect in every way. Her only weakness is her forbidden love for her brother.  While she is the flawless and perfect one, Tatsuya is the irregular and worst one (oh the irony). In reality, Tatsuya is made to look like the perfect one and Miyuki the worst ones thanks to the plot. Almost every time a problem shows up, Tatsuya is the one who fixes it. I really liked this twist in the anime. Now, the actual plot is about Tatsuya who enrolls to Mahouka Koukou as a reserve or Weed while Miyuki enrolls as a Bloom, one with better test results and stronger magic capabilities. Right off the bat, we get introduced to fantastic characters who are friends with the siblings, all with varied and unique characteristics. Miyuki is adored by the entire school due to her being a Bloom as well as good looking while Tatsuya is discriminated and looked down upon for being a Weed. Yes, a cast system at a high school. This discrimination is short lived for Tatsuya as he proves himself to be more than meets the eyes. I won't spoil why but it's definitely badass. 

TL: DR

It's about two siblings who enroll to a school where one of them is discriminated and the other adored. The older brother joins the student council and gets involved in serious shit. The rest is about a sort of contest between different schools and action happens. 


Art: The art style is fantastic and it has that subtle futuristic feel to it. The colors are vibrant and make the world feel alive, being a perfect mix between redundant and realistic. The characters look unique and they really fit the story of the series looks. Background and nature are not the focal points of the anime but they look very nice and I didn't notice anything strange about them as the series progressed. There isn't a lot to say about the art other than what has already been talked about so I am moving on.


Sound: I must start off by saying that the two main protagonists Tatsuya and Miyuki's VA did an outstanding job voicing them. They fit the characters perfectly and were exactly how I wanted them before the series came out (I read the light novels before). They are flawless and I  doubt anyone else could have done a better job, let alone compare. The music intense during action scenes and has a techno vibe to it. During dialogues, the music is calm and relaxing. I think the music is superb, but the only thing that's missing are a bit more varied music. Some tracks repeat themselves.


Enjoyment: The action scenes are very fun to watch with really cool moves being performed. Couple that with the outstanding animation and you get some of the best action in anime history. I feel that the number of action scenes can be a bit underwhelming and the dialogues that dominate can be off-putting but nevertheless, it is still really enjoyable. That isn't to say that you can enjoy the series dialogues but if you are looking for nonstop battles, look somewhere else. Oddly enough, the incest can be quite enjoyable as it is almost comedic at times. Romance is not the focus of the anime but the only romance you'll find is the incest. 


Overall, I think Mahouka is one of the best anime in recent years. It really is good and enjoyable to watch. I highly recommend watching it, even if you find some of the stuff to be unenjoyable. Give it a watch and judge after the first four episodes or so.

*This review might contain spoilers* 
I normally don't write reviews but I had to get this off my chest. Not the best review ever ( maybe the worst.) There is a TL:DR at the end.
Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei was an enjoyable in the first episodes. I assumed that the show would be great since the Light Novels were the most popular in Japan and U.S. (I think U.S.) It even had potential to be amazing. Boy was I disappointed when I finished the show. Still unsure why I went all the way to end of the show when I could have just dropped it inthe middle.


Story: 3/10

I'm aware that the story gets better after the end of the adaptation but I will only review the ones the adpated. The story is either everywhere or it just drags on for like 8-9 episodes. The show is pretty much fillers the entire time with no clear story spotted. As for pacing, its like a fat kid running as fast as he can for a little then to walking .1 Mph ( .016 KmpH.) 


Character: 2/10

The main character Tatsyua is like Kirito (Sword Art Online) since Tatsyua is so damm overpowered and looks perfect. He can solve problems that people have and fix it in a fucking flash! Dude calculate pretty much any magic and what that spell would be. He can see through walls and even win a fight just by snapping his fingers. Also can REVIVE PEOPLE BACK FROM THE DEAD with his magic. The man even killed guys with one punch to the face. His Sister has a thing for him and almost did something that me yell at my TV for almost doing what she was about to do. As for the supporting characters, they were to many of them and they were flat and static as hell (Shizuku best girl.) Even the villlians were just carboard since there is nothing behind them and just terrorists 


Art: 8/10 

Even though the show had some problems, what made the show a little bit better was the artstyle. For me, I really enojyed this the most of the show. Character designs were fantasic and I will admit that they looked good. the only problem I had was the kind of colours it used since most of the show I saw white that any other colour but it was a big deal.  


Sound: 6/10

The VA's did a great job for there character roles. But other than, it was the soundtrack that brought the score down. For me, It was not that good. I didn't like the music choices that they used for the fights and the score just seemed forgetable. As for OP/ED, that was the only nice ones.


Enjoyment: 6/10

Even if I gave the show low marks. I still enjoyed the show. The only reason for enjoying it was because I turned off my brain and sat back. At glance, Tatsyua might be the most bad ass person in the world. If your brain is off, you will enjoy the show. If you leave it on, you will hate the show with a flamming passion.


Overall: 4/10

Some people loved this show to death while others want to see it rot in hell with School Days or some other show. For me I just don't want to see this show or hear about again with it's bad storytelling and boring characters.


TL:DR: Mahouka has good Art while everything else sucks. No good señor.

Going into this anime, I was expecting a borderline average plot about some school that does magic and a character that has to prove themselves despite their position. What I found was something unexpected, with quite a few things worse than my initial assumptions, but somehow made up for with a few absolutely brilliant things.
Character (5/10): This is the worst area for a reason, it simply didn't develop enough.
+ Tatsuya (The main character) is a total badass. Although little about who he actually is and why is shown by the end, small things manage to build up piece by piece parts of who he is.While it appears that his only emotions are related to his sisters wellbeing, over time this just doesn't appear to be wholly true.

+ The student president as a counterweight to Tatsuya and her own ideals was pretty interesting.


- Tatsuya really wasn't developed on enough.

- The student president was generally sidelined, and her relation to Tatsuya grows to be just like the others over time.

- Every other character (I'll give credit to Erika now for being one other who has some other defining characteristics) seems to be built on their relation to Tatsuya; Some characters would follow him even if he was a lemming jumping off a cliff, some only revolve around a rivalry or desire to destroy him. There is no in between for some reason and this kind of destroys and nuance between characters apart from their magical powers.

- There is a really overplayed and in your face thing between Tatsuya and his sister. From Episode 1 it goes on and while it seems to be some unrequited romance, it is kind of unnecessary, and the time could have gone into other characters development.


Story (6/10): The story seems to be more focused on power building than anything else.


+ A positive of not knowing a lot about Tatsuya for a lot of this is that anything which reveals more is actually genuinely interesting. In this sense, the pacing of the story is actually decent.

+ While not integral to the main plot, the story does at times tackle some interesting questions such as whether people just go after their perception of equality for their own position, or if they actually believe in going into it for merits sake.

+ While few moments actually make it in, some of the comedy here was pretty good.


- There really wasn't enough development of the main antagonist(s) going into the next season. They did something to Tatsuya and seem evil is about as far as it goes.

- The story is kind of let down by the characters. A lot of the plot seems to be taken up with keeping characters relevant whenever Tatsuya gains power himself.

- The characters though are also let down by the story. The story essentially reverts them to deus ex machina devices who advance the plot in various ways. Additionally, some arcs appeared rushed, leading to underdeveloped antagonising characters who were a disappointment compared what they were expected to be.


Art (9/10): This goes along with the sound to make the absolute highlights of the anime.


+ The battle scenes are amazing.

+ The battle scenes last a long time and are amazing.

+ Did I mention that my God the battle scenes are amazing?

+ There is some awesome art at the second ending which just somehow makes Tatsuya seem even more badass than he already is.


- I'm only going to begrudge them a very small amount for not being Ufotable Fate Zero level of style in the fights.


Sound (9/10): While it doesn't have a real negative, it's not a 10 because I've heard better.


+ This goes brilliantly with the fight scenes.

+ I really found the second opening to have quite good music.


Enjoyment (9/10): You should have guessed it: The fight scenes make this anime.


+ The fight scenes. Yes i'll mention it multiple times because every time I saw one in an episode I remembered why I was watching one after another.

+ The pacing of this wasn't fast enough to confuse me, but neither was it slow enough to bore me.


- The brother sister thing really wasn't needed in this and kinda threw me off at points.


Overall (8/10): Main points of both good and bad:


+ Yep the fight scenes will keep you coming back. I'm not sure if that's more just because you learn more about Tatsuya or more because they are actually brilliant, so I'll go 50/50 on both.

+ The soundtrack on this one is actually pretty good.

+ It didn't give away enough that I did want to watch more episodes.


- The brother sister thing again. It kind of puts a dent in an otherwise completely different story.

- The characters are seriously lacking in some respects. A couple are pretty good, but most are too generalised.

- The story essentially feels like a set-up to a bigger season. While I don't mind that terribly, it does feel like some things were intentionally not developed on in order to make this the case.


Overall while Mahouka appears for the time being to be lacking in the overarching plot, and has deficient characters, it's good enough overall to retain interest throughout the whole series.
