This is my favorite anime. It's one of the few "smart" anime out there, it's beautiful in its art, and there are plenty of characters to love. By smart, I mean it feels as though a physicist or an engineer wrote this story. The theme is that magic has long been dismissed as legend and is now technology and goes into great detail on how spells work and magical theory. It is a bit hard to follow if you don't pay close attention or are uninterested, but there are 4-5 short episodes that you can watch to prepare for the show, which explains how magicand the society works, as well as introduces some of the characters. There are a few things that many people don't seem to enjoy about the show, one being the science of it, as I mentioned. The other aspects involve incest and the main character's emotionless state. The love between brother and sister in this story leads to a lot of implied incest themes, which goes beyond the norm, but hey some people are into that. However, this relationship is explained further on in the story and if you're not into the semi-incest then bear with it and see that there's more to it later in the show and in the manga. The main character, Tatsuya Shiba, is often considered by viewers as emotionless and cold and hard to like. However, he is supposed to be that way and there are reasons that you will see later in the show and it is well worth it once you realize how he's one of the most OP, badass characters ever created. If I were to be any character I'd want to be him because he is charismatic, intelligent, a natural leader, confident, and has goals and everyone in the show loves him. The other characters are very likable and the class president Mayumi Saegusa has effectively become one of my fav anime crushes. I definitely recommend this show but be sure to keep an open mind throughout.

Watch the irregular student at magic high-school as he surpasses his upper-classmen, classmates, basically everyone. The irregular in question, has a sis-com and a big secret.
Now, Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei has plenty of ups and downs. Unfortunately, I believe I can list more downs than ups. 
Before I begin, I would like to tell you, I'm judging the anime to after I have read several of the novels, the anime covers the first 7 novels of the series.
When I watched it for the first time, I thought it was an amazing anime. This is because of the plot and the logical explanations of why themagic worked and partially watching a supposedly low achiever (the underdog, or as they say, the weed) be better than people who are supposed to be better than him (the blooms). However most of the anime was logical explanations of magic. 


There were lots of names and characters to be wary of, there were figuratively +10 names you had to remember to understand the dialogue. I had to watch the episode several times and use the wiki to pinpoint who was who when watching the anime. It got frustrating. 


Then, there's the magic. The characters got shocked with the magic being used, but because we're not in their world, we can't understand why they were shocked, we can't understand why that bit of magic was impressive compared to the rest of the magic and why some people couldn't use magic that others could (I’m excluding Tatsuya, because he has a reasonable reason as to why he can and cannot do some magic).


Watching the anime, you will come across a lot of things you just won't understand, for example, what they are doing, why they are doing it, what they are thinking and, just what can the main character, Tatsuya, do??


To answer these questions, you will need to use the wiki or read the novels.


I enjoyed the anime when I first watched it, watching it after reading the novels, not so much.


On the contrary, I would recommend people to read the novels and answer the questions you still have from the anime.


Honsetly, I lowered my original rating for the anime after reading the novels because the anime cut out a lot of parts I felt were crucial to the story and they altered several parts of the story. I bumped the anime down a whole 2 grades upon the second viewing. On the up side, the anime does help you comprehend what the novel is talking about.

Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei or The Irregular at Magic High School as it is known in English, delivers in depth knowledge of magic, incest, op characters, and cartoony villains all with mixed results.
Story: 5/10
The setting takes place in the distant future, in the year 2095. By this time, magic has become the ultimate source of power and whoever has the gift to control it can achieve greatness. The story follows Tatsuya Shiba and his younger sister Miyuki as they navigate and adapt to their new settings at the prestigious First High School for magic. Tatsuya is placed in the Course 2 classes after excelling inone area of the entrance exams and failing the other area being labeled a "weed", while Miyuki tops the entrance exams and is place in the Course 1 classes being labeled a "bloom". The story is separated into 3 different arcs: the Enrollment Arc, the Nine Schools Competition Arc, and the Yokohama Disturbance Arc. The Enrollment Arc follows Tatsuya and Miyuki as they adapt to their new high school and meet new friends such as: Erika Chiba, Leo Saijo, Mihiko Yoshida, and Mizuki Shibata. This arc includes themes of discrimination and espionage, in which Tatsuya gets caught in the crosshairs when he befriends another Course 2 student named Mibu, who becomes involved in an anti-magic terrorist group known as Blanche as well as a group that protests the labels "weed" and "bloom", and the main plot involves thwarting their plot. I would have to say that this was the most interesting arc of the entire anime, even though that it is more or less forgotten by the beginning of the next arc and not really connected to it either. The Second Arc is the Nine Schools Competition Arc, where Tatsuya and friends compete in an Olympic style competition to determine which school has the best magicians. This is the arc where I lost interest in this series as it was nothing more than info dump after info dump and showcased how OP the characters were with its predictable ending. Finally, the third arc is the Yokohama Disturbance Arc, where after Tatsuya is given almost all the credit for the predictable victory of the last arc, he continues to show how OP he is during another competition and ensuing battle with another terrorist organization. If these last two arcs sound silly to anyone, its because they are. I mean come on a terrorist organization that targets a group of OP high school magicians, how wacky, cartoonish, and outlandish can this plot possibly become?


Character: 4/10

Easily the weakest component of this anime was the character cast. The supporting cast is quite possibly the weakest cast of any anime I've ever seen. But as for the main characters first you have:

Tatsuya Shiba: He's our main protagonist, introduced as the titular "irregular", he is initially portrayed as an underdog that we're supposed to feel sympathy for, however, that trait is quickly put to bed when we discover by the second episode just how OP, he is when he defeats the Vice President of the Student Council in the mere matter of a few seconds! Talk about OP!!! As for his personality, he's pretty dull, socially inept, somewhat robotic, and maybe even a little arrogant. It also doesn't hurt that literally every FUCKING girl has to point out how great he is!!!!!!! He's just a cookie cutter Gary Stu, a boring, bland shounen protagonist.

Next we have:

Miyuki Shiba: She's Tatsuya's younger sister, and hands down the most annoying character in the entire anime. Each of her scenes vary from cringe inducing to just plain stupid. She has zero character development and exists solely for the point of trying to make Tatsuya more human and care for something when he barely shows any emotion throughout the entire anime. Her biggest character trait, is her incestuous love for her older brother. Now let me mind you, I'm an American and here, incest is considered taboo and held in very low moral standing, so I'll go ahead and say that I fucking hate when this particular storyline is used to enhance the drama of any anime, I find it very unnecessary. So, needless to say I never warmed up to Miyuki's character at all, she was nothing more than a Mary Sue to Tatsuya's Gary Stu, a product of the occasional untasteful type of fanservice, and an incestuous pervert who almost went so far as to attempt to  violate her own brother in his FUCKING SLEEP!!!!!


Next, before I give a very brief description about the supporting cast, I thought I would focus on the dynamic of the sibling relationship between Tatsuya and Miyuki, that didn't involve incest. I honestly didn't find their relationship all that great. It lacked the close bond that exists between siblings in most shounen anime and I found that disappointing. It's also why I think incest in anime is a shitty plot device because it takes away from what could've have been a compelling strong point for the series.


Now as for the supporting cast, you aren't going to find anyone dynamic. The female side of the gender coin basically drools over Tatsuya and constantly praises him for how wonderful he is, while the male cast simply acts as Tatsuya's support whenever necessary, and nothing more. The only supporting character that I found decent were Erika, Leo, and Mikihiko if they had received more development or were the main characters then this could have been a better story, imo.


Now that my rant on most of the negatives of this anime is finished I will now focus on the positives.


Art: 8/10

The art and animation were produced by Madhouse one of the greatest anime studios our there. The characters were well drawn and the setting was also quite lovely. The animation is also a high point and executed well during the battle scenes, despite the OP nature of the characters, but I digress.


Sound: 9/10

The music in Irregular at Magic High School was excellent on the other hand. LiSA's  "Rising Hope" was used as the first opening theme and imo is the best song used in the anime, she has also done some excellent music for other popular anime such as: Angel Beats!, Sword Art Online, and Fate/Zero. The second opening "grilletto" by GARNiDELiA was also quite catchy. The endings were fine as well.


Enjoyment: 6/10

Despite its many flaws, I did enjoy this anime to an extent. I enjoyed the first half particularly more than the second half. As noted before, my interest in the series waned after the unwarranted Tatsuya praise. This anime ranged from occasionally fun and illogical to sinfully boring.


Overall: 6/10


One final note, I have not read the light novel that the source material is based off for this anime adaptation, so I can't comment on which is better.

Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei or known as The Irregular at Magic High School, is a future based anime that is usually passed on due to its title or some other reasoning. I'll be reviewing this anime with the knowledge of reading the LNs' and rewatching the anime a few times. Note that I did not read the fan translated light novels and I read the Original Japanese version instead due to unofficial translations, please understand. The fanbase's translations may be done really close but I'd prefer to read the original if I can.
This anime has many pluses that make it interesting and great.
1. The artworkand animations are great. Not a single thing threw me off besides something I'll tell later on.


2. The voice actors did an amazing job connecting with the characters personalities and emotion.


3. Our protagonist is a badass including his little sister.


4. Comical timing is done really well, each time something funny came up, I got a laugh out of it.


5. The explanations behind how something happened are explained really great, almost anyone can understand the most confusing thing if they pay attention.

6. A simple and well though out or straight forward plot.


Basically, what I'm saying is that if you like action, this show's got it.

If you like great artwork, this show's got it.

If you like Imoutos', this show's got it. 

If you like badass characters, this show's got it. 

If you like great explanations on behind a situation, this show's got it.

If you like school life anime, this show's got it.

If you like stuff like that, watch this anime, the following cons will not stop you from enjoying it.


Like many anime, this one is not perfect. Despite having many great things about it, there's a hefty amount of cons...


1. Characters, meaning the side and supporting characters that is. The characters introduced later in the story, lets take Kei for example, have no background or true motives. We have no information on what's their personality, goals, and skills. Literally, the only reason they're introduced is just to hang out with the main protagonist, Shiba Tatsuya, because somehow, people gravitate to his character. If they weren't even introduced, the anime itself would not be even changed at the least if they were removed.


2. Like many anime of this generation, CGI, or Computer Generated Images, has become a commonplace. This anime has quite the amount of them too. Because how well the artwork is, it makes CGI stand out way too much in comparison. You'll see CG models either walking, sitting, or just being there in the background. Just to fill in as students of sorts. But what surprised me is that how hidden they are, sometimes you cannot even notice that they're CGI, unless you're paying attention or just really good at noticing the difference. I saw them as blurry characters in backgrounds.


3. Random ass OST. In some scenes, they'll just play music that doesn't even match with the situation. The OST isn't bad or anything, it's just the really bad timing of music placement. 


4. New people to anime may find the Bro/Sis-Con relationship really disturbing in a way.


5. They try to force a somewhat harem onto Tatsuya, but he does not give a damn.


6. Plot holes, a lot of them too. If you're an anime adept, you can figure these out pretty easy.


I gave this anime an 8/10. The reason is that, the anime itself was interesting and fun to watch. Compared to the light novel, I ma say it was a bit rushed but in the end it was great otherwise. Anyone who likes this type of genre will enjoy the show to the fullest no matter the cons. It was worth my time and surely mostly a lot of other's too. This show, in my opinion is suitable for newcomers and veterans alike. If you want to watch something good to watch to pass time or spend your free time, go ahead and pick this up. It'll be worth your time. You have a synopsis of the anime provided by MAL, go check it out.









P.S.

Onii-Sama is badass.

Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei is a mixed bag of good fights - exzellent art and music and story but unfortunately a bad deconstruction and character development. Its sounds harsh, but it makes it a choice, like it or like it not - it ultimately needs investment and it isnt easy to simply sit down and look it. It feels a little rushed, let me explain why:
The story has you follow Tatsuya Shiba and his (not so) younger sister Miyuki. They both live in a world where magic became a part of the military arsenal, magicians are trained to be death machines and dominate their battlefield,for this 10 highschools opened and Miyuki and her Brother join the First High. 

What you will notice in the very first episode already, is the very overly attached sisterly love that miyuki has (which sometimes extends to rather akward situations.) For Bleach -Fans , im not talking from a combination like Byakuya und Rukia, but a much more attached one.

Anyways, the two of them join the highschool and after passing the test , they are confronted with some of their classmates being bullied from people that have a flower sign on their vest.

This will be explained in the next episode but basically , the schools do separate classes for weaker and for superior magicians and call them ,,Weed'' and ,,Bloom''. Unfortunately you see very often that Tatsuya or his friends are underestimated for this reason and like you surely can guess, their enemy was defeated anyways.


This is however a major plotpoint, since what happens next is a quarrel between two kendo clubs , tatsuya - now joint forces with the disciplinary squad- saw them being buliied. The captain of the Weed-Kendo club -Mibu wanted then to talk to him. She said she felt herself and the other ,,weed'' student bullied and wants tatsuya to help her change that, yet he finds her resolve not worthy and thus he left her sitting. 

Later you find out that she has been decieved by an enemy organisation and ,,Blanche'' which wants to attack japan and take informations from their main database. 


The point is that the story seems very fast, even with 26 episodes you feel like everything runs from a-b in split seconds - trying to explain or leave it open. What is surely new and refreshing is the Art style and the premise. In that world ,2 different kinds of magic exist, first is modern magic which bases itself around a CAD - a device that a magician wears as a cuff or weapon to amplify spells fast. And older spirit magic, which requires time for the magician to prepare. Both are very well introduced and fit to the universe, it is especially shown at the end of the first arc - when they hold a competition between the schools, thus a good amount of cool and interesting spells are seen.


Sound is...not very interesting , that is if you are a sound lover like me. The first opening and the fighting theme nail it with a techno-ish beat. It makes you feel pumped for the fight and be like ,,yeah!! beat him down!'' I ultimately dont remember any other theme to be exceptionally special. It was a little bit disappointing for me, at least in this point.


Characters, are honestly not that well explained - or at least , there were often things that were questionable which ultmatively lead to read the manga or the novel for more information. One particular scene bothers me very very much , while the other ones could be understood to an amount, this one really is not an understandable choice for me. In an episode at the end, where the Great Asian Alliance attacks, was the first high school cornered in a conference room. The military (naturally) comes conveniently to save them before the main enemy force could join and proceed then to greet Tatsuya as their special officer ,,oguro''. Now you'd expect his friends to say something like : ,,Omg Tatsuya, Why didnt you tell?'' or something like that - right? Doesnt Happen. Everyone seems calm and confused even though it was confirmed that their friend was a super agent, working for the military. Later Miyuki even explains that he has a live saving ability and their was no question at all like ,,Why does he have that? Why didnt he tell us?'' Its a bit strange and makes you feel weird.


Overall however, I think I had a good time with looking the story. Even though it is sometimes extremely confusing, there are also a lot of times where you get good and exciting fights and themes.


Thats why I issue Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei a 7.5-8.


I hope this review could help you, dear reader :)

=MAY CONTAIN SPOILER=
The Anime starts at the year 2095 where magic is a reality and instead of using weapons to fight war they use magicians that was trained thru the 9 affiliated Magic schools by the government. The anime contains 3 arcs from the LN plus one if you include the movie 
First arc is enrollment arc where they introduce the First High, the school of the MC, each school has 2 courses in which called blooms and weeds (Reserves) the students are put to a certain course based on their magic activation grades etc but not based on combat like hand to hand andmilitary grade magic and this is where the MC comes in with her blood related sister 


The MC known as Shiba Tatsuya or Godsuya either is fine is placed as a course 2 student (weed) and his sister Shiba Miyuuki top 1 of the upcoming 1st years and placed as course 1 student (bloom)


First Arc is Mostly Discrimination between blooms and weeds

Second Arc is some sort of school olympics where they battle plenty of events all 9 schools competing

Third arc another school competing event but in magic thesis


The anime focuses on action and fantasy magic with explanation (quite hard to understand at first) the story itself is great making a future world where magic is invented and things the may lead into potential world breaking problems,

The Animation and Sounds are greatly synced into together and when magic fighting they did not save budget on anything just watching tatsuya handle hand to hand combat in the first episode is already amazing 

Characters are great with each individual having development AND NOT FALLING in love with the MC where other characters get their own relationships but do take in note the incest between the MCs but dont let it annoy you they wont do something that couples usually do yeah they tease people thru words only tho (for now) theres a reason why they have a relationship like that will be slightly explained thru out the anime

I enjoyed the anime so much where the MCs is too OP but not well known and well done i rewatched the anime 8+ times and will rewatch it more! The action is trilling and exciting with the combination of synced sounds animation.... 



Overall Anime is 10/10 (id give LN 11/10)

The anime would be better if the magic is explained more (i read some of the LN to understand the background and Magic use)

Just don't mind the incest and you'll be fine

Hoping for season 2 so they can explain briefly about the Magic And Background of the fantasy world

During and after World War III, magic became the main military weapon, that is to say, not only military but also civil. This magic is a little different from what we see in other anime, it's a kind of technological magic activated from CAD's that I'll talk about next. CAD's (Casting Assistent Device) are instruments that help in the use of the spell leaving it stronger depending on the user. Usually CAD's look similar to cell phones and calculators (actually look more like "metal wallets"), but they can also resemble bracelets, gloves, cards, weapons and even swords. To use magic, the characters enter a seriesof codes pertaining to the desired spell. A concussion in the concept of student values begins to occur with the arrival of Tatsuya Shiba, a new student of course two, who despite being harassed and despised by many students of course one, proves to be a true genius with great skills and powers, the Which go completely unnoticed in fitness tests. This shows that the evaluation system is too generic to assess individual talents and that they completely escape established standards.


Tatsuya Shiba(司波 達也)

Tatsuya is the main male protagonist of the work, he is a tall young man, with a good athletic structure, has short, dark hair and has blue eyes, most of the time we see him in the school uniform, during the story he demonstrates To be somebody serious and extremely intelligent, not to mention that it is very risky to say a little cold and calculating, but one time or another makes a joke, although he almost does not change his expression of the face to give the impression that he was serious. Tatsuya joined the Disciplinary Council at the request of the council chairman, due to the level of his knowledge and his exceptional vision, being able to read the activation of a spell quickly, find out what its nature is and also is able to neutralize it. Secretly he works as an agent for a national security agency, and so is the mysterious software engineer and CAD known as "Taurus Silver." Tatsuya protects her sister at all costs, he is like a "guardian" for her.

Miyuki Shiba(司波 深雪)

Miyuki is the main female protagonist, Tatsuya's younger sister. She is a bit short compared to Tatsuya, she has long dark hair and blue eyes, she is recognized as the most beautiful by both the male and female characters as well, she shows in the anime a little shy, but it is worth mentioning that She certainly has loving feelings for her brother, and if it were not for the blood ties, they might have a love relationship. As for her abilities, in almost every battle she uses a very strong freezing spell that also manifests itself when she is irritated, Miyuki is the representative of the beginners and undoubtedly is a high class magician, is not atoa Which was for first year, and very quickly became part of the Student Council.

Mayumi Saegusa(七草 真由美)

She is the president of the first college student council, and in my opinion, the most beautiful character in the anime. She is friendly and approachable, especially with Tatsuya, after all, * I think she likes him. Most of the scenes she and Tatsuya are together, she asks if he does not get nervous about a girl as beautiful as she is.

Erika Chiba(エリカ千葉)

Erika is a student of Year 2 of Year 2. She is the youngest daughter of the Chiba Family, one of the families at the height of the Hundred Families. She is classmate of Shiba Tatsuya and not long after she became a constant friend and companion of the Shiba brothers. A good mage, and has a lot of experience with swords, which is something that has come from many generations of the Chiba family. Erika is a very fun character, extroverted, with a good sense of humor and almost always with the high astral high above, but of course when the matter is serious, she does not play.

Leonhart Saijou(西城 レオンハルト)

Saijou Leonhart is a student of First High School, a year 2 Course 2. He is also referred to as "Leo". He is the first male student who approached Shiba Tatsuya on the day of registration, and has since been his companion and friend. On the appearance and personality Leo possesses Germanic traits, brown hair, green eyes and an athletic body. He is also considered handsome and has met the interests of some girls. He has an easy personality and a brilliant disposition along with a straightforward and straightforward attitude that often leads him to heated discussions with Chiba Erika. He has an inhuman resistance, and uses a fortification spell most of the time. Leo is easily motivated or persuaded to do favors, I find him a very fun and strong character.

Mizuki Shibata(水木柴田)

Mizuki and another classmate from Tatsuya of course 2, he met her along with Erika. Mizuki is described as a shy-looking girl who wears glasses. In their day, it is rare for girls to wear glasses because a vision correction procedure is already widespread. Tatsuya correctly inferred that their glasses were to reduce their over sensitivity to Pushion energy, allowing their "crystal eyes" to even perceive the hidden aura and the exact nature of the spirits. Regarding her personality, despite being a shy person, Mizuki is the person who loses patience with the rude actions of the students of Course 1, for example, during the first day of class, when a group tried to persuade Miyuki to join they. She provoked Morisaki Shun, the leader of the Bloom student group, which almost resulted in a "magic battle" between students, which is forbidden at school.

Yoshida Mikihiko(吉田幹彦)

He is a direct and confused character, although he seems calm, he is also very shy when he is with mizuki. His magic is very important in reconnaissance missions by controlling spirits of various shapes and elements.

---THE PREJUDICE---

Specifically in the first college there are two forbidden but widely used terms: BLOOMS and WEEDS. The Blooms have an extreme contempt for the Weeds for being in the second grade and being "dumb".

---Blooms---

The Blooms are students of Course 1 of the first college, these were the ones who took good marks in both practical and theoretical exam. A detail of them is that in their uniform in the part of the chest and arm the symbol of the school is stamped.

---Weeds---

The Weeds, in turn, are those who took bad or reasonable marks on any of the exams. Unlike the Blooms, the Weeds do not have the school symbol printed on their uniform. Tatsuya was the first student to score 100 on the theoretical examinations of the selection process for the first college, but he was recruited for Course 2, because his marks on the practical exam were very bad.

It's like they remade Code Geass and turned it relentlessly boring.  It had a ton of elements I normally like: a futuristic, intricate, and vaguely dystopic setting; cool main character; unique scifi elements; decent animation.  But the whole time I felt like I was waiting for the plot to start.  And it never did.
I listened to hours of explanations of magic, and watched countless scenes demonstrating the main character's power.  The whole time, I was optimistic that it had to be building to some kickass storyline where all the intricacies of the magical system come together in some sort of catastrophe.The main character's ridiculously hyped powers would finally not be enough, and the audience would be left in awe of this new challenge that can take down the great protagonist.  But it didn't happen.  There were some cool looking fight scenes, but no one ever seemed to be in danger and no character development occurred.\n\n
All in all, it was a huge disappointment.

tl;dr version/summary in the last paragraph.
Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei is an anime adaptation by studio Madhouse of a highly acclaimed light novel series of the same name. In honor of the upcoming movie and the fairly recent start of the publishing of official English translations of the light novels, I decided to write this review so that I might raise some awareness and maybe help someone discover this series that I greatly enjoyed.
However, before I start with the review, there is one thing I must adress. There are plenty of people out there, that despise this show for a variety of reasons. If you despiseincestuous undertones, you should probably leave now, because they're very apparent in Mahouka. If you have an irrational hate of overpowered protagonists, this show is probably not for you either. That said, I think most people who hate this show for that reason have a serious case of hypocrisy, as the same people seem to love One Punch Man. If however, those things don't bother you, I urge you to read on as I explain just why I like Mahouka so much.


The story starts in year 2095. The world has been ravaged by famine and war, and the population of Earth is only a small portion of what it used to be. The only reason a nuclear apocalypse was avoided was due to discovery of the magic at the dawn of the millenium, and the solidarity of the world's magicians in eradicating nuclear weapons. After several decades of relative peace, our two main protagonists - siblings Tatsuya and Miyuki - are about to enter one of the prestigious magic high schools in Japan and trigger a course of events that will change the people, society and the world around them.


I personally find the universe of Mahouka to be absolutely fascinating. The amount of thought and detail the original author has put into it blows my mind. While the anime does not let us fully appreciate all the detail, the visualization and the beautiful art by Madhouse is truly a fine replacement. Everythings from clothes (for the record, Mahouka has the coolest looking school uniforms ever period) to everyday utilities to buildings and infastructure looks absolutely amazing.


Mahouka's cast of characters is also very well done. The character designs are interesting, all the characters have plenty of backstory to them and they all have their unique way of being badass. Not to mention I absolutely love the character dynamics, and there's an abundance of potential ships for all the shippers out there. Despite having a massive cast of side characters, it handles them admirably.


On a side note - the Oreimo-Mahouka crossover memes are hilarious.


Saying that the soundtrack of the anime is "different" from most anime is an understatement. The OST has music from a multitude of genres, and the music itself ranges from emotional to light hearted to epic. While I definitely enjoy the OST, and it definitely fits in, I feel that the composer tried too many different things, which makes it feel like something of a jumbled mess. Both of the two openings of the show get you hyped up, whilst the two serene endings let you peacefully lay in your chair while you think back to the episode. And although I might be somewhat biased on this matter since the show has a good deal of my favourite seiyuus (voice actors), I think the voice acting and casting is overall very well done.


The story itself isn't anything that special. It's formatting is fairly generic for novels, where enemy "X" is trying to interfere with event "Y" and the protagonists must stop them by solving a mystery involved. But the sheer amount of content and depth put into it does fill the void somewhat.


Now for the biggest downfall of Mahouka's anime adaptation: exposition. Since it's based on an extremely exposition heavy light novel series, it can be difficult job to translate all that into the dialogue. Without the existence of a proper narrator, plenty of things will be left unexplained. I found it particularly ridiculous how the anime failed the explain the abbreviation "CAD" (casting assistance device) which is probably the most single used item and second most used word (after "Onii-sama", which you will hear approximately every 3 minutes). If English is not your first language, you will probably struggle understanding what on earth is going on, when the characters start speaking in mostly scientific vocabulary.


During my first time watching Mahouka, there were several times where it had to rewind the video, pause, carefully read a line and ponder it's meaning before I fully understood it. It's kind of like science class, except with magic. If you've read the light novels first and already know what's going on, this won't be a problem to you, since you're already familiar with the terminology and can focus on the beautiful visuals. But obviously, reading the novels shouldn't be a requirement for understanding the anime, and that's something the anime adaptation fails horribly at.


As everyone who knows anything about Madhouse can attest, they're really good at at making action scenes. Mahouka is most certainly not an exception to that. I can with full honestly say that it has some of the most stunning and badass fight scenes ever made. I distinctly recall the pain of my jaw dropping to the floor several times while watching this.


To summarise, Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei is a sci-fi, magic, action show based on a light novel series of the same name. The main character is a badass and completely overpowered. His sister is a massive brocon. The visuals are stunning and the fight scenes will make your jaw drop. The exposition is overall poorly done, and will leave you confused unless you've read the novels or are willing to rewind multiple times. There's a large and interesting cast of fleshed out characters with interesting pasts and numerous ideals. The character dynamics are awesome. The OST is a weird mix of numerous genres, but it does it's job well enough. Overall, I feel it's done very well, and every episode gave me an irresistible urge to watch the next one (I binge-watched the whole thing). I rate Mahouka as a solid 9/10.

I am baffled as to why this story is so popular. The best I can say about it is that it was "fine, I guess, if you have 11 hours to waste in the least gratifying way possible."
The good
The world has a very complex magical system that the characters will tell you all about in an extremely boring, unhelpful way. But I guess it's consistant and thoroughly explained, so there's that. The art also wasn't terrible, however I have to say I found the use of 3D modeling a little jarring. It didn't fit in with the style of the art at all, and allI can chalk it up to was either laziness or lack of funding. It looked sloppy, clunky, and just...bad. Sorry, this was supposed to be "the good" section. Spoiler alert: the best thing about this is the art, and even that isn't very good.


The bad

I suppose the worst part about this is that there was never any suspense. It's very clear by episode 2 that Gary Stu Wonder Boy (aka Tatsuya) is going to get everything he wants without even having to work very hard. He makes a big show of "not wanting to be in the spotlight" at all ever, and yet somehow he always always always ends up not only involved, but right in the center of it all. There's an unfair discriminatory policy towards course 2 students? Well, now that Tatsuya is here, suddenly everyone is against that unfairness.  Secretly, the student council has been against it all along! There's an amazing CAD engineer who can make the impossible possible? Jeez, I WONDER who it could be???? What, our entire team got wiped out right before the finals of Generically Important Sports Competition?? But they don't usually allow replacements?? But this time they will??? And guess who it's going to be??? Tatsuya?!?! Whhaaaat?? Crazy. 


This show is ridiculous, honestly. It was almost laughable in how predictable it was. The last arc was by far the worst. The MC is OP, yes. But honestly, he's not the only one. Let me summarize something that happened with not one character, but two (at least): "Hey Dad. Yeah, we got caught up in a terrorist attack...again. Could you send over some helicopters? Sweet. thanks, Dad! You're the best!" Seriously. That happened. TWICE. There's also this weird incestual overtone that is played for jokes...kind of. I really don't get why it was included. It added nothing to this story. Not to mention that OPMC gets a harem for...no reason in particular? He regularly expresses opinions that are unfeminist at best and misogynistic at worst. He never hesitates to tell a girl that what she is wearing is "inappropriate". Even one of his teachers! To be fair, the design of this particular teacher is pretty much "talking boobs". She, like all of the characters on this show, is given no character development.  This anime is set in 2095! Are gender problems still that bad??? How depressing. 


The final nail in the coffin of this show is that there is literally no point. There's no overarching goal the MCs are trying to accomplish. No Big Bad to defeat. No internal struggle to overcome. The last episode heavily indicates that there's more to the story. So maybe there's a lot of context missing that the Light Novels go into. I'm not sure; I have literally no desire to spend any more time with this franchise.


If you want to watch a MUCH BETTER show about a clueless bodyguard high school aged soldier, go watch Full Metal Panic. Don't waste your time on this anime. Just...don't.

Mahouka...mahouka...mahouka, judging by the score you might I hate it, and you are partially right, but I don't hate the show as an entity by itself but more of what it stands for. And here is the thing, Mahouka is not an entity by itself, by itself it is merely an average gary-stu story, I have seen at least 50 similar works in surfing Qidian all of them pre-date Mahouka. But Mahouka gets the hate because it signalled an era, an era of utter putridness that is coming forth to swallow us whole, the era of horrible WN adaptations. (Well technically SAO takes part ofthe fall, but its effect is less than Mahouka's)


Story - 2


The story gets 2 marks, 1 for actually trying to pretend it have one and 1 for all trying to explain things in techno bullshit. The thing is the entire story can be summed up in one phrase "Tatsuya (self-insert name) is awesome!" Yes that's it, Tatsuya is Jesus, and anything in his way shrivel pathetically in front of his almighty finger poke of doom. Politics? Setting? How do they matter at all when your MC is so OP, that nothing matters at all. There is no real stakes, no real conflict, all the politics, all the fancy explaining, they are all deception creating an illusion of depth.


The story like almost all these terrible WN adaptation is simply a masturbation power fantasy.


Character - 1


Miyuki is an annoying mary-sue, created by the author to be the perfect waifu for him (You should read the part in the novel describing her, the author fanboying is very creepy). Beyond that she is nothing more than an extension of Tatsuya.


Which bring us to the halbringer of WN OP protagonist, Tatsuya. He is emotionless except he does have emotion, he is OP, a genius, and basically good at everything, and as for the "feel other people pain" part, that is totally bullshit, he have no reaction at all. Pain is shown, pain is when the MC fall to the ground screaming, looking pathetic, and showing your weakness, trembling unable to get up. Tatsuya have none of this, so "Pain" my ass.


As for other characters, when a black-hole-sue exist, all other character cease to have any purpose other than be insects for tatsuya to step on, or worshippers who kiss the very ground tatsuya walks on.


--------Effect on the LN industry-------


See the word "weakest" in bahamut's title? The trend of "MC-kun have is actually super-duper awesome and the school is flawed" is popularized by Mahouka's success. But there is an even more terrifying result.


Mahouka's success had opened the flood gate that used to hold back the abominations of WN, but now the seal is cast off, and the WN tide now sweeps towards us. Things like GATE (Xenophobic propaganda power fantasy/Spunkgargleweewee), Overlord (standard Qidian power fantasy), and many not yet animated WN turned LN are flooding forward. It would be like the dark age of Qidian all over again, power fantasy running rampant, all challenge is lost until the medium is known as nothing but a putrid pond of masturbation. Now the LN industry is pretty much dead with half of what it output being "pretty pictures and toilet paper" with the other half being "Power Fantasy Masturbation"


Do you see the problem of this kind of shows now?


Overall - 1.5


Like I said, Mahouka by itself is not too much of an abomination (it still is), by it self it probably deserves a 3 or 3.5, but the result it caused is catastrophic, and due to the horrible personality of its author, the entire thing deserves a 1.5 out of 10.

Oh, the Irregular at Magic High School; the anime I love to hate.
The character development is practically nonexistent, especially near the end, when new characters are introduced and the watcher merely has to accept that they are 'good' or 'bad', nothing else. The colours used are bland, and Tatsuya Shiba is essentially a one-man army dealing with the threats for an entire school. There's also those weird moments approaching incest with Miyuki, something I feel should have been left out.
However, for all its shortcomings, the battle scenes are glorious and exploring Tatsuya's psyche and lack of magical powers is in-depth. The animation style makes theuniforms seem sharp, a selling point for the anime with otherwise boring animation choices. Repetitive music, but used to great effect.\n\n
Overall good impression, but with a few things to work on for the next season.

This show won't contain spoilers, but will gloss over some of the story arcs.
I see a lot of hatred for this show, and while I am not surprised, I am a bit saddened. I wrote a review for this show back when it was in ep 16, and have since completed the entire show at least 4 separate times; the only other show that I've seen so much of was Code Geass.
I would like to start with the biggest complaint that everyone seems to have with this show: the main character, Shiba Tatsuya. While this anime most certainly seems to be your run-of-the-mill show featuringmagic and highschools, you'd be wrong to believe that you'll find here what you've found in countless other shows. Having now seen my fair share of anime, I know that your average MC is usually someone who doesn't know much about what's going on, is somewhat clumsy, is extremely squeamish and often times find himself following other people's plans, even if s/he has doubts about it, and is extremely powerful. 


Having said this, a few of the readers may think of a few shows that do not do this; personally, Code Geass and Death Note (two of my personal favorite shows) come to mind. In my previous review, I compared the MC from Code Geass and from Death Note to the one portrayed in this show, which upset a lot of people. The truth is, all of these characters are pretty much the opposite of what I just described as being the average MC, aside from power. It would seem we can't have a show where the less powerful defeat the more powerful without becoming more powerful themselves.


Story: 9/10


One of the most astonishing things about Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei is the pacing. It's slow; very, very slow. I was initially thrown off by how slow it was, and held it against the show; however, as it progressed, I started to realize how great it was that it was taking its time. Truth is, this anime does more than tell a story; it paints a complete picture of how magic works, why it works, practical applications, the effect that power and the lack thereof has on people, has reasonably extensive background stories for nearly all of the secondary characters. If you simply want a fast-paced action show, run away as far as you can from this one.

Truth be told, the way this show likes to detail how everything fits together reminds me of Tolkien's works with Middle Earth, and that is not a comparison I will do easily.


The one thing that I truly dislike and that feels the most out of place with this show is the extremely strong brother complex that goes on between Tatsuya and Miyuki. I understand that the sister has to like her brother (for that one thing that happens later on in the show to happen), but this is just overkill.


Art: 9/10


I'm not good with art. I like the simplistic, clean look of the characters and the environments, even if they can feel a bit lacking at times.


Sound: 9/10


I usually don't really care about sound. I just don't notice it for the most part; however, Code Break has joined my music library as one of the very few songs that I have bothered to get from anime. I really enjoy the mix of drums, whistles, vocals and dubstep. It really added quite to the few battles in the show.


I did, however, deduct 1 point for the weird violinish songs played during brother complex segments. Just no.


Character: 10/10


I mentioned characters in the preface. I would say that MC does not change throughout the show, as this show is primarily about revealing who he is and what he can truly do. However, all other character significantly evolve around the MC, which is made possible through the slow nature of this show. It's quite interesting to see the change of mentality and how people change their opinion of Tatsuya throughout the show.


Truth is that I really wish all MCs could be like this. I have no personal interest in shows where the MC is "clumsy, fiery and lovable". However, opinions are like assholes; everyone has one. I just happen to enjoy cold, calculating MCs that rely on their intelligence rather than their "guts" to complete challenges.


Enjoyment: 10/10


I can count the amount of anime shows I've seen a second time in one hand. I'll even list them: No Game No Life (4x), Code Geass (4x), Death Note (2x), Highschool of the Dead (2x) Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei (4x). Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei is one of the few anime shows out there that encourages the viewer to actually think about what they're viewing. This is a show that is best viewed while thinking about what's being presented to you. If I had to find the exact opposite viewing experience, I would say Gurren Lagann; a show good in its own right, just as long as you don't think about it and just enjoy the spectacle of robots larger than galaxies throwing, well, galaxies at each other.


Overall: 10/10


I actively search for shows similar to this one quite often. Not many exist, and often times they can be quite buried down in their rank, as they're not necessarily the most popular types of story. This is most certainly a good acquisition as the 5th show I give a rating of 10/10. I really hope that there will be a second season.

To start, I have NOT read the manga. That said, I wouldn't know if this is a great chapter-by-chapter adaptation or not. 
Tatsuya (mmc) is a refreshing look at a shounen lead. He is neither weak, OP. He has his flaws, yet is a dominating force that can be admired. The same cannot be said for other characters. Many characters are sterotypical. You've got the overly shy (Azusa Nakajou), the moe glasses type (Mizuki Shibata), the silent "android" type (Shizuku Kitayama), as well as many other tried and tested anime tropes. In fact, there are so MANY characters introduced, that even in 26 episodes moreoften than not, character development is lacking.


Additionally, the story is rather erratic at times. I did like the division of the series into arcs, and I enjoyed the story overall, but significant details were either glossed over or left out completely. We get a glimpse of Tatsuya's background, but that's all. I would have liked a little more explanation on what exactly was done to him, how rare he is, and a deeper look into his relationship with his "sister" Miyuki and the non-existent relationship he has with their family. Again, a 12 episode one-shot series, I couldn't expect much. But I expect a little more cohesiveness and development from a 26 episode adventure. 


The basis of the story is interesting: Magicians developed as weapons. Seeing this power grow and how it could be abused made me excited to see more. The series also took a more scientific approach with the presence of magic through CAD's (which were never fully explained either). 


Overall, it's not a bad series. I would hesitate to settle in for 26 episodes if you're on the fence about this one. I can't imagine there are not better options out there. But on concept alone it's a win for me. Execution makes it average.


If this series gets greenlit for another season, I hope there is more explanations and deeper character developments, and not just the fan service kind.

Mahouka is not a story about an underdog struggling to break social stigmas and stereotypes, nor is it a show about whatever else it tried to be about. It's a show about the man, the hero, the legend, the universe - the brilliant Onii-sama.
=Writing & Directing
It's straight up shit. Even though I overall enjoyed the show it's not really good in any regard but its way of being bad can be really amusing. The story itself can be divided into a few acrs each loosely connected around the same theme of how magic affects the world of mahouka: be it discrimination based on ability, technologicalprogress or military resource. None of that really matters cause in the end there's little in terms of exploration or resolution to any of that. The only thing that matters is that awe inspiring Onii-sama is amazing and nothing can be done to stop him.

The show gets a bit more boring after Nine Schools Competition arc cause more focus is put onto side characters and plotting evil organisations but action also steps up a notch so I guess it's fine.


When it comes to characters it's about as mediocre as every anime out there, most of them can be adequately summed up with just one word that described the way they feel or act majority of the time, some are permamad, some are always halfway to orgasm and so on. The spotlight of course is magnificent Onii-sama who apparently can't feel a damn thing other than hatred for anyone who dares hurt his sister. It would be a huge downside in every other series but seeing him knock every asshole or a confident prick down a peg is so satisfying that it's probably the sole reason I watched the show. The thing is, at first virtually every other character hates the great Onii-sama simply because magical test and class systems in his school are kind of dumb, so despite being a prodigy when it comes to engineering and theoretical knowledge of magic, amazing Onii-sama is considered a second class citizen cause his practical use of magic is nowhere near good. His otherwise otherworldly skills are the reason why people say there's no tension in this show, there isn't because it's not a question of whether fantastic Onii-sama will win or lose, it's a question of who will he destroy today.


Another part of writing that's important to note is the sheer amount of unstoppable exposition and technobabble, it's gonna take a simple thing like blasting someone with magic really hard and then try really hard to present it as complicated techno-magic science which sometimes makes glorious Onii-sama's victories all the more amusing.


Don't have any complaints when it comes to directing, it doesn't stand out but it's still competent when it came to pacing and delivery on exposition dumps. I've seen better shows that were harder to get through due to above being badly done.


=Art & Sound


While the designs for almost everything are bland, the color coordination, use of digital effects, filters and overall consistency are fairly decent and animation quality is good when it needs to be. As for sound the music while not great still did a decent job of setting the mood and feel for some scenes. There were some questionable things like constant autotuned vocals with occasionally jarring engrish or one comedy track that had rasta influences but otherwise there's some good variety to it and it doesn't feel like one of those cheap OSTs made by an doujinshi circle of amateur artists whose specialty are tracks so bland you would never be able to tell who made them.


Overall it's a really shit anime but it's kind of shit that's fun to look at in the right mood.
