Awfully bad anime. Hell of a good preview. I honestly hope it gets a sequel and it lives up to my expectations, because if it does.. Oh boy.

So first off I'm watching anime for about half a year now and on one destined day I stumbled across this Masterpiece of an anime with, at least practically, two different plots, which both take about one half of the whole season. Actually I' don't even know how I learned about this anime anymore, but whatever, I'm definitely glad I did. 
So now to the anime.
The story takes place in the year 2095 after a World War and is about the protagonist Shiba Tatsuya, who enrolls at a Highschool for Magicians together with his Sister. At first everyone thinks he stands in the shadow ofhis sister,which is but in reality he is a genius with prodigious history, who is sworn to secrecy about it. From time to time his fellow students realise that he is more than they seemed to notice at first. And he uses this fact to his advantage to weaken the discrimination between the higher and lower class students in that school. He established himself not only as a genius magical engineer, but also as a magician with astonishing physical and magical abilities. \n
That said, it's hard to deny that he is probably one of the strongest and most overpowered characters I've ever seen in an anime but he has a rather great flaw since he has nearly no emotions. But even this is one more fact I like this anime since he has such an unclouded mind and analyses everything with a cool head. That doesn't mean that he is a totally irrational douche with no understanding for feelings an emotions.\n
And so to sum it up, it's really an anime I would recommend to everyone, even if it really starts to roll at the 5th episode but if one can overcome that you are sure to be rewarded, believe me :D

Mahouka 8/10 - is very good, but has a big flaw
---------------SPOILER FREE-------------------
Great Anime, a mix of action and comedy/romance. It has a great story split into 2 arcs of seperate "incidents".
Set in a High school where students are split into 2 courses it deals with the issues of discrimination mainly until a certain point.
The big flaw with this anime is the main protagonist. He's a really ridiculus character, which makes things kinda stupid.
The things that differ from this world, that make magic possible are really irritating me, since they introduce facts that are
either wrong to current understanding or just don't fit into this worlds rulesvery well, which are then used in Mahouka nontheless.\n
Its like someone saying:" Hey, here 8/9 is 1, but all other Math laws apply", which is NOT POSSIBLE, but with programming things.\n
I'm not saying thats "bad" or something that shouldn't be done, but its very irritating to someone of knowledge.\n
The first arc is great. It introduces the viewer to the mechanics that are present and talks about real problems, that we have too.\n
The storyline is really interesting and has a good way of hiding the way the arc is going to play out, which is really good.\n
Characters introduced here are well done and carry a meaning in existing, altho Mahouka has a few filler characters.\n
The ending of the first arc is well done and has no cliffhanger whatsoever, so I recommend stopping here. Just stop after the "last dance".\n
Overall the second arc is good, but it feels really rushed towards the end. The arc is set up well at the start, but the setup is so big,\n
that it cannot really finish everything of in the last episodes. In this arc the unexplained/crazy stuff happens.\n
It feels like someone said:"WE DON'T HAVE ENOUGH ACTION" and they just filled episodes with fights that are pointless to show.\n
I also feel like the setup of the arc overhypes whats going to happen.\n
Still, it doesn't break character or the worlds setup so I hope they make a followup to this arc.\n
All in all, a great storydriven anime, really no big logic loopholes and interesting concepts of magic.\n
I enjoyed it and would recommend it.

I found this show enjoyable if only for the fact that the magic/animation of magic was really cool.
also the world and events like the (spoiler) magic tournament thing with breaking ice towers and magic surf boarding was fun.
thats it...
I could not connect with the main character ether by loving him or hating him.
He seemed to be incredibly overpowered in terms of magic. A bunch of the show seemed to be proving how amazing the main character is-all the things he can do. also the characters surrounding him were a typical harem and didn't stand out in my view.
I would still recommend this show because someof the fight scenes/events in the tournament were fun and the art was pretty good but don't pick this up for the plot/cahacters

Problems in the show,
1. Lack of background character's reactions to gore.
2. Long and annoying explanations about how magic works.
3. The Protagonist does things that pretty much break the logic of the show to the point where its a turn off.
4. Lack of overall knowledge of the world the show presents along with character histories.
There are a few more but those are just a few off the top of my head. I did enjoy the show but its a hit or miss for some people. I would recommend watching it.

A story, weaved through paper or computer, is supposed to incorporate elements that are common to a plot, such as rising action, climax, and falling action. These stages of plot development are usually driven along by either character development or action sequences, all with an end goal in mind. In SAO, it was to get out of Aincrad alive. In Love Live, it was to participate and ultimately win Love Live. In Pokemon, it was to become the very best, like no one ever was. However, Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei, else known as The Irregular at Magic High School, defies these common standards. It isa story that does not focus on its action sequences too acutely, for the main protagonist is too overpowered to serve as an equal opponent to anymore. Since the main protagonist is overpowered and literally emotionally dead, character development also is negated. So what happens in this show? Something extraordinary, in the fact that the plot is guided along, not by characters, not by action, but by the pure virtue of the plot itself. Here is a show that does not adhere to normal story-telling procedures, and instead forges its own path, using anything other than the protagonist to drive the story. The protagonist is not just the main hero of the story anymore, but rather a kind of savior known only in fantasy.


Story: 9/10

The story isn't terribly original, but it is wonderfully executed overall. However, the interesting thing to bring the score up so high is that it seems as if the show starts out at the middle of the story. The beginning is not explained, but rather revealed in hints and snippets through the entirety of the series. The background of the siblings is hinted at at moments, along with their precarious relationship, but is not fully expounded upon. This sort of tantalizing gesture would normally cause a score to go down, but the story arcs themselves are so interesting and engrossing that it is truly hard to drop the show. From the beginning of the school year to the summer break tournaments, The Irregular makes the plot interesting with a constant state of tension, relieving the stress occasionally with good comedic moments that make the plot feel relaxed and fresh. The story hides the tension easily, concealing under a slice-of-life type of setting. It is a wonderfully crafted story that trumps the holes left by a mysterious backstory of the sibling protagonists.


Art/Sound:

Madhouse truly put full efforts in the animation of this show, as every combat scene, every slow-motion effect, even the cafe sit downs, look excellent, with the proper lighting and excellent shading in every single aspect. The semi-3D effects, the spell circles, the character outfit designs, all of it are excellently planned out and animated. The sound within the show is very good as well, and the two openings are catchy and upbeat, while retaining that high-energy feeling the show emanates. The last ending, however, deserves to be praised for its sound. Rei Yasuda does an excellent job on "Mirror", and it nicely closes off the last few episodes with a strong sound.


Character: 10/10

Although I did previously say that the story is not character-driven, that is the exact reason why I gave this section a solid 10/10. How can a character that is already fully developed, with a complete backstory and locked in with his emotional state, develop even further? Simple, he can't. I'm sure there's arguments that could argue that the sister could've changed through the show, but the sister's own feelings and unchangeable, and thus making the main characters change would be untrue to the plot itself. If the main characters don't change, then the side characters pick up the slack slightly. Though I won't mention specific characters, in the end, the side characters do develop nicely from the beginning to the end of the show. However, this development does not make a difference in the plot overall, as the main protagonist siblings completely overshadow them in power. This unchanging nature of the characters is what deems this section a 10, because the directors realized that changing the characters would not be staying true to the plot, and thus the 10 is to symbolize the characters' true worth as unchanging stone characters that can defeat anything that comes their way.


Enjoyment: 10/10

The show had its funny moments, exciting moments, its tense moments, and its angry moments. The show is a rollercoaster, but it doesn't feel too fast or too slow at any given point.


The Irregular at Magic High School does not fit within the normal stock of plot and conflict, in the essence that the conflict, which should contribute to rising action and ultimately the climax, does not result in anything at all due to the sheer power of the protagonists. It is a show which does nothing and yet everything within its plot. It is a show of two separate dynamics; of both change within its side characters, and stagnation within its main characters. This combination of two seemingly opposite tropes makes this show an utter masterpiece that manages to make two opposite themes attract. If you're searching for a series that does not rely on its protagonists and instead focuses on the setting and the story more, look no further, and have no fear, for all will be solved by power in the end.

Overall: 10/10

OVERALL - 8/10
If you are new to anime, have been living under a rock for a few years, or just awoke from cryogenic slumber, you may not have heard about The Irregular at Magic High School. If you have heard of it, but haven't watched it yet, I don't know what you are waiting for. There are many reasons why you should watch this anime, and I will go through some of my favorite reasons why you need to watch:
1. Packed to the brim with Onii-sama - This anime has more "Onii-sama" than any other series, and most of them combined. Research done while boredhas proven there to be 172 seperate utterances of "Onii-sama" packed into 26 episodes. Thats over 6.5 "Onii-sama" per 24 minute serving!\n\n
2. The most ridiculously OP MC in history - Yes that's right, Tatsuya is the bastard love child between Saitama (One Punch Man) and Hermoine Granger (Harry Potter). He can do anything when it comes to the magic system used in the story. While I am sometimes bothered by overpowered protagonists, because he is so far over the top I found it more entertaining than grating or annoying.\\n\n
3. Its Madhouse - Madhouse is not known for producing poorly animated shows, so its no surprise that The Irregular at Magic High School is a beautifully drawn and animated show. \n\n
TL;DR - In short, come for the "onii-sama" but stay for the animation. This may not be the most innovative or unique story out there, but for what it is (AKA Magic School Battle story) it is a type specimen and a ruler to judge other Magic school batlle anime against.

- Includes spoilers -
The story is about the siblings Shiba. Tatsuya Shiba who was made a weapon by his own family and his emotions were taken. Only his love for his sister Miyuki remains with him. So the two siblings visit one of the few magic high schools in the country. Miyuki as a student and Tatsuya as her secret bodyguard. The secret love of each other, the everyday life between school and military and family clan make this anime unique and worth seeing.
I really hope for a sequel and I also hope that both come together, even if it seems ethically reprehensible.
Thank you foryour attention. Wishing you a nice day!

I enjoyed this anime. But in the middle, it is starting to annoy me. Okay, sure, this male character is just so OP that no one can beat him. I can take that. But noooo, his sister has to have a crush on him! If it is just brother and sister relation, I can take it, but unfortunately, no it is not. It is great that they want to incorporate romance into this, but this is just too....not my taste.
Well, but I guess the OPness and the great drawing made up a little bit for it. The magic scenes were drawn beautifully and the characterswere all either handsome or pretty(with normal hairstyles). 


This anime has:

1. Action

2. Fighting scenes

3. Great character (OPness)

4. Romance

5. Drama



I hope you enjoy this anime. It is still pretty good after all since I managed to finish the whole thing. Cheers

When I First Heard Mahouka Koukou No Rettousei I Didn't Took It Seriously Until The  Itself Got Surprisingly High Rating At The Time Of Its Finish. So When I Watched The  I Fairly Enjoyed It Like I Watching SAO Or Rakudai Kishi No Cavalry But With Different Style Of Uniqueness. 
Since This  Is Adaptation Of LN I Wouldn't Compared It In Light Novel Point Of View. This Is My  Point Of View:
The Story ? Well, I Found It PRETTY GOOD
*Well, The Story Centered In Two Protagonist Enrolling Same Magic School But With Very Different Degree Due To Entrance Results. At First,I Found This Nothing Unique But As The Story Progressed I Realized There's More Complex Story Than Just Ordinary Lives Story Of Protagonist And I Pretty FASCINATED And CURIOUS About It.


*The Plot Pace However Can Make Some People Bored Because It's Pretty Damn SLOW But It's Okay For Me Because They MAKE UP For It In The Awesomeness Of Action Combat Scene And Brilliant Strategic Thinking Scene. History, The Governments, Magics, Socials, And Politics Were Explained In Great Detail Making Me Even More EXCITED With The World In Mahouka Koukou No Rettousei. 


The Art ? I Think It Is EXCELLENT

Madhouse Has Done It Perfectly. The Animation Was EXCELLENT, The Movement Was Pretty AWESOME In Action Combat Scenes, The BG Was Also NICE. I Found The Character Design Was Pretty GOOD Too, They Designed It Not Too Excessive Or Not Too Bland. The School Uniform Was Also Pretty COOL Too.


The Sound ? Hmm.... Well I Think I HAVE NO PROBLEM WITH IT.

The 1st And 2nd OP/ED Was NOT TOO BAD I Think And I Have No Problems With It (Even Though I Often Skipped It Both For Saving Time) The OST Is Also Pretty GOOD But Not Particularly SPECIAL For Me. 


The Character ? I Think It's GREAT

*If You Know Kirito From SAO I Cannot Deny It That Shiba Tatsuya Has SAME Characteristic In Terms Of Overpowering Power As Kirito Did. But While Kirito Is Freeloader Type Personality Tatsuya Are Cool And Genius Type Personality. Some People May Brand Tatsuya As Siscon Type Since Tatsuya And His Sister Miyuki Has Harboring Love To Each Other More Than Anyone Else. I Think Tatsuya Is GREAT Character. He May Make You Confused At First Due To Complex Personality But Almost All His Action Was To Protect His Beloved Sister. 


*Then We Have His Sister Shiba Miyuki. She Is Intelligent, Capable, Beautiful, And Sometimes Pretty Moe. She Always Very Obsessed With His Brother Tatsuya And Even Her Friends Calling It Lovey-Dovey Relationship Rather Than Familial Sibling Relationship. I Very Enjoyed It Watching Their Relationship. She Also Sometimes Jealous If She Seen Her Brother Dating, Charming, Or Blushing With Another Girls And I Found It Pretty Hilarious To Watch. While Some People Thinks Miyuki Is Pretty Annoying Or Bothersome But In My View Miyuki Pretty INTERESTING. 


*The Supporting Characters Are Also Making Me INTERESTED About Them. Supporting Character Pretty Big Almost Equaling Shirobako's Side Charcters. 

However, There Is One Supporting Character That Make Almost Have SAME STANDING As Main Character It's Name Is Mayumi Saegusa. She's The Only Person That I Very Remember The Most Due To Her Capability To Trolling Tatsuya To The Same Caliber He Troll Others And Her Affection Towards Tatsuya.


*While Mahouka Koukou No Rettousei Triumphs In Dodging The Cliche's Or Confusing Situation Unfortunately It FALL SHORT Of Expectation In Supporting Character Development. If Supporting Character Development And Plot Was Very Good Mahouka Koukou No Rettousei May Will Be In Top 5  In Spring 2014


The Enjoyment ? I ENJOYED IT VERY MUCH 

Although At The Time I'm Hyped About Another MadHouse Project  No Game No Life Which Released At The Same Time. But I Didn't Regret It Nor I Hate It , In Fact I Was Very Grateful The Decision To Watch Mahouka Koukou No Rettousei Proved To Be CORRECT One. 


Overall Mahouka Koukou No Rettousei Is Very Good . Pretty Satisfying And Very Enjoying To Watch

Mahouka, despite what it may appear, it isn't an action show, and it isn't really a harem or even romance show. What it is, rather, is a Science Fiction show that just happens to contain some anime cliches and stereotypes, for better and for worse. Mahouka is very centered on world-building and introducing it's viewers to the ins and outs of it's setting, as well as creating a plot that centers very heavily on said world-building.
Story(8) - Mahouka introduces us to a world where magic has been slowly gaining prominence, and is on the cusp of changing the political and technological landscape of the planet.Mahouka starts off with Tatsuya Shiba, the protagonist of the show, arriving at First High, one of several academies that are dedicated to the advancement and study of magic. Magicians are ranked according to their proficiency in casting spells as well as their ability to influence "Psions", particles that are the catalyst of Magic. While Tatsuya is ranked as one of the lower class students, various events bring him to the attention of the student council, who quickly realize that while he may have been ranked low on the tests, Tatsuya's practical and real-world application of magic far outstrips any of his other classmates, and he is inducted as a member of the discipline enforcement branch, to show off his inner kirito to all the other helpless non-main characters in the story.


Well it's easy to see where the anime influence shows itself, but right around here is where the show starts to get interesting (also i will be refraining from mentioning any further specific story points, can;t have too many spoilers)


At this point the show starts to really shine in my eyes, as it starts to focus on the interactions of magicians, and the work said magicians do. In a nutshell, the first arc covers the politics of First High, the Second Arc Covers the interplay between the academies, and the third arc focuses on the use of magicians in conflict between countries. Mahouka is at it's best when you can sit down and marathon and entire arc(typically 7-8 episodes) in one go. The story doesn't hold up very well when watched piece mental, as some episodes can be nothing but exposition, while some episodes can be entirely devoted to conflict. Either way, the story holds together quite nicely, and escalates at just the right pace, giving you time to adjust to the new scope of action.


Art(8) - The animation in Mahouka is what you would expect of an anime coming out in 2014, the visuals and characters all look anime, and there is never really a drop in quality at any point in the story (Even the CGI is implemented responsibly, something that is often hit-or-miss in shows). The artistic design team did an excellent job, the cities and outfits all have an interesting blend of modern style and architecture pushed through a futuristic filter. The magic spells are a great treat to watch, the smoothly implemented special effects make the spells appear both menacing and otherworldly.


Sound(9) - The music of Mahouka fits the theme of the show perfectly, with varied techno, dubstep and otherwise "current" music trends. While I normally wouldn't think of a "wub wub" kind of mix fitting this anime, it surprisingly does the job, and actually gets you pumped up in the action scenes. The sound effects are both visceral and well designed, with very little stock sound effects thrown in, most if not all of the design seems to have been originally created for the show. If you have headphones or a decent surround sound, definitely use those.


Characters (6) - The characters of Mahouka are for the most part quite likable, and despite the sheer number of supporting cast, each person has their own distinguishing feature to help set them apart. While the show doesn't make time to explain the backstory of nearly anyone, it doesn't really detract from the interactions they have with one another, leading to varied and enjoyable dialogue. Since they are the main focus of the show, i'll do a quick analysis of the lead protagonists.

Tatsuya- The protagonist of Mahouka, Tatsuya is a reserved young man with ties to one of the most powerful magician families who is trying to strike out on his own. While Tatsuya may initially appear to be the completely overpowered hero who can do no wrong, we quickly realize that if your job name is "magician" your so far above normal humans that Tatsuya no longer appears to be the god he initially seems to be. Part of this is how the show goes in depth to the mechanics of how magic works, and how Tatsuya approaches Magic. The further into the show we go, the more Tatsuya appears to be a person who has achieved such strength through equal parts natural talent and hard work. This makes all the difference between a character who is insanely strong for plot convenience, and a character who actually deserves to kick so much ass his foot smells permanently of farts.

Miyuki- Now on to the reason characters received a 6. Miyuki is Tatsuya's doting sister and...thats it really. Her character is so unbelievably devoid of, well, character. Her sole purpose is to say "onii-sama" every chance she gets, and to generally be a bitch. Matters are not helped by the fact that she is the overpowered for no reason archetype, and we aren;t ever given any explanation for why she is so absurdly strong. Her annoyance is further compounded by the fact that she figures prominently in every arc, so we are never really given a chance to forget her.


Enjoyment (8) - Despite Miyuki dragging down the show, as well as some very uneven pacing in the episode by episode info dumps, Mahouka is easily one of my favorite Sci-Fi shows to come out in awhile(Live action included, not just limited to anime). The mechanics of the Mahouka's world are genuinely entertaining and interesting to watch, and excellent production values just make the ride even more enjoyable.


In closing, if you are looking for a heavy-duty science fiction show, I would highly recommend Mahouka. If you aren't into sci-fi, or are looking for just some mindless action fun, DO NOT assume this show has these characteristics. Scientific exposition and even some political intrigue are the main courses of Mahouka, while action is just a delicious side-dish.

WARNING, MAY CONTAIN MINOR SPOILERS!
The Irregular At Magic High School / Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei
Review By: John Fragglepuss Evans
I felt that The Irregular at Magic High School went at too slow of a pace for my liking. Every little detail had to be explained. Something would happen for a minute and then the rest of the episode would be characters hashing out why it happened the way it did. If this style is what you enjoy, then this anime is right up your alley.
The concept of magic was interesting and the story had potential, but it was too slow and fell flat in its delivery.Just my opinion.


You might enjoy this if: You like to hear technical explanations of how and why everything happens.


You might not like it if: The strange brother/sister love scene that occurs on occasion in anime bothers you.


Note to the Viewer: This anime takes all the sexiness out of magic.


EXPANDED REVIEW:


Our anime group, Salt Lake City (SLC) Anime, reviewed The Irregular at Magic High School this month and here is what the group thought:


The group was split on what I mentioned earlier about the pace of the show. Some people enjoyed the slow, explanatory pace while others did not. Some people were bothered by the brother/sister love situation while others were not. Some people thought the character development and interaction left something to be desired. There were some that really enjoyed the connection of magic and technology combined with how everything was explained in great detail. One person mentioned that they really appreciated how the anime would give you some detail and then leave the viewer with a lot more to think about. Overall, people either loved or hated The Irregular at Magic High School.

I've always hated the fact that magic does not exist. Yet, I believe that technology will advance so much one day that we will be able to call it magic. And imagine this now, just ten days ago I came across an anime that kinda pictures that "Techno-magic" I was thinking about. I'll let you now enjoy the review on "An Irregular at Magic High School". 
 Plot and Story Line 
You remember maybe how Sword Art Online did that story-line thing, where the whole plot is actually made up of shorter stories (SAO, ALO, GGO...). Well, you have the same situation in AIAMHS too.They tell one shorter story in about eight episodes, and three or four such stories made the show. But what is this anime about now?

As I mentioned in the beginning, magic is not magic how it used to be. Instead of colorful spells, bright lights, stars, cepters etc, you have codes. One code, one spell and they are all casted by Casting Assistant Devices, or in short CADs. The CADs are all designed and made by magic-engineers. One of those, and very talented one, is our protagonist Shiba, Tatsuya. Still, most of society knows him as just Tatsuya, a first-grade student at First MAgic High School. Because of his "bad test results" Tatsuya made it only into the second course, while his sister Miyuki attends the first course lessons. That's basically it about the plot. The short stories now are mostly result of governmental affairs,  competitions, and teenage problems. Talking about teenage problems, I kinda got used to first-degree-cousin-relationships in anime, bit this went to far. This could have been the best sibling-relationship ever, but no. Let's make a romance of it. I mean that looks just ridiculous. That's the first problem I have with this anime, but it can be overseen somehow. The second problem is way bigger. It's not a huge, it's an enormous plot hole. What or who is Tatsuya, who is his aunt, what happened to his mother, why is his family acting like this? This anime leaves all these questions open, just like that. However, I liked this anime enough to believe that this is not the end. I think, or more hope, that there will be a second season that will answer all the questions I have.  But despite all that, this anime still has a point that blends out the cons at least for a little bit. One word. ACTION! This anime has one of the best action I've ever seen. The fights were just epic, with so many different powers and bad-ass characters. I was amazed. Both thumbs up for that. that was also the most interesting thing about this anime. 

My first thought about this show was "Techno-Magic, really?". I mean it kinda humiliates the good-old magic we all know. However, it was interesting and fresh. Something new. It proved that there are still some makers that don't lack in ingenuity. Who would have ever thought that sci-fi and magic could be combined in this way. "The Irregular at Magic High School" (If only they had a better title).

Characters 

Now we come to problem three in this anime. The characters. The personalities are basically are the same, there is not a single character development and no uniqueness at all. There are maybe four or five characters that stood out a little bit like Erika, Sayaka and Misaki, and of course the main Tatsuya. But that's it. Still, as always I'll introduce you to the two mains. Tatsuya and Miyuki.


SHIBA TATSUYA. Dear makers, was it possible to make Tatsuya even better? I think not. He was perfect, and I hate perfect character. He is strong, unbeatable, good-looking, smart, charismatic, should I continue? He was invincible. Although it was awesome to see him fight, his personality was boring. Also it was impossible for him to develop his character. I didn't like him.


SHIBA MIYUKA. This is probably the most anoying character I've ever seen. She is cute and everything, but sooooo annoying. Still I have to say that she is a caring, talented and hard-working girl. She is also kind of that perfect characters that everybody adores. One of the cutest scenes in the anime is when Masaki, from Third Magic High School, askes her to dance with him. Kawaii. 


Animation and Style

This is one of the pros of this show. The animation is just perfect. I really enjoyed watching it. It shone the most in the action scenes. The way the spells were casted was so amusing. I loved it. When it comes to the style, it's probably nothing special. Just standard character looks, landscapes and backgrounds. On the whole it was good, no objections here. 


Conclusion

Well, well, well. An Irregular at Magic High School was a good anime. It is not a waste of time, but there are more better anime worth wasting your time on. It is amusing, interesting and catchy. The thing that made me like this anime is probably the fact that it reminded me on my school and system. My school also has some kind of first and second course, and competitions with our "Sister-Schools". Try this anime I hope you will like it more than I did.  

Your AnimeGirl

Now, this anime does have flaws. But why is this ranked THIS LOW? It has flaws, but not enough to put this anime this low. I thoroughly enjoyed this anime. There is a good story, good characters, good visuals and mediocre to good sound. Yet for some reason it is said to be a bad anime by a lot of people. Obviously this isn't the majority, as this anime would have an even worse score that it already does. But it truly baffles me that an anime, by MadHouse, that has a good plot as this, and great assets like good art and sound, couldbe ranked and rated this lowly. 


Story 9/10

This anime is the kind where the main character is seemingly powerless against the rest of the school, but is revealed that he is actually really powerful. This anime does this type of story pretty well, for a light novel, as there are a ton of light novel animes that are really bad.

I also thought that the idea for CADs was a really cool concept not seen in much anime.


Art 10/10

The artwork is beautiful. The magic., to the special effects, it adds to the fact that magic really isn't magic in this world, which is a concept I really liked.


Sound 7/10

There wasn't anything that good in this department, but nonetheless I liked it as a mood indicator, as most songs fit their parts. Nothing great though.


Characters 7/10

This is the worst part of the anime. One of my least favorite kind of characters are the ones that love their siblings, especially if that sibling is the main character. This is why I absolutely HATE characters like Leafa/Sugu in SAO and Shizuku in Chivalry. It makes me cringe every time I see a fanservice or intimate moment between sister and brother.And that's EXACTLY Myuuki is. Hate it so much. Like the rest of the cast.


Enjoyment 9/10

This anime was fun to watch, but Myuuki put a damper on my enjoyment. I like everything about her except the fact that she's smitten for her brother. My favorite character, who was the most entertaining to see, was (call me weird) is the main character. I like seeing how characters like him adapt to his changing surroundings, like Haciman/8man from SNAFU and Houtarou from Hyouka. 


Overall 8/10

This anime was a blast to watch. Though I hated Myuuki, the rest was fine, and I liked it a lot. This would go on my top 10 if I had one, but as my enjoyment does not determine the overall, an 8 was the most I could give.

I love this anime, I enjoyed the Story, Art (gotta love MadHouse), Sound, and most of all the characters.
For me I enjoy the conversations, everything does not have to be action all the time and the talking gives it more plot details and find this anime very calm and suddle.
Its much more better than those animes with the loud mouth idiots that won't shut the hell up and those annoying and obnoxious perverted comedy animes with stupid perverted admires and fan boy and girl clubs.
I love the characters also, people complain about Tasuya having no personality and I actually love that, it makes him badassand calm like Heero Yuy from Gundam Wing which no body bitched about him from what ive seen and a little like Kirito from Sword Art Online with him being OP and I love very calm and OP main characters from animes like Alucard from Hellsing.


Its far more better than Eren from Attack on Titan, which gets pissed off, emotional, yells and becomes a male damsel in distress all the damn time or like Rito Yuuki from To Love-Ru which acts like a total panzy ass and freaks the hell out when it comes to girls.


Miyuki, I find her very cute and likable and I enjoy her being a bro-con she's like Mihato from They are My Noble Masters and a more cuter and eloquent version Mikasa from Attack on Titan with a little more personally and with some Kikyou from Inuyasha slapped it.


Okay now I know what to say, recently ive been hearing people complain about it being raciest against Asians because of the main villains group, which I consider a bunch of bullshit. I saw them as a fictional organization thats try take down certain clans and you guessed it, take over the world, also thats what the main villain group was in Firefly.


Some interesting trivia, Tatsuya is based off the Hindu god, Shiva The God of Destruction and Miyuki is based off the goddess Parvati, Shiva's devoted wife.


Also In Japan, The Irregular at Magic High School was the best selling light novel series of 2014.

This anime was one of the few that I actually re-watched. I really did love it.
Now I'm a sucker for anime like this, with the magic and all the drama, it really is one of my favourite types.
I really did love idea of having a magic school and the way the use the CAD (Casting Assistant Device) to use magic.
The conflict between the two groups, the course 1 and the course 2 students in the first arc because it starts off the anime with a load of drama and I loved that.
I also loved Tatsuya, I'm not really sure why, It's just the way hedidn't really give a shit about anything and well I liked that.\n
I loved the characters as well, they were funny and lightened up the show when it got rather serous at times.\n
The animation really was pretty as well with how they showed the magic and just how everything was presented it really made me swoon. If an anime had pretty animation I will be on it quicker than you can say animation :P \n
I have watched this anime like 3 times because I really, really liked and each time I was hooked.\n
I liked the fact it was split into three separate arcs because it made the story a lot clearer and easier to follow.\n
My favourite arc was the second one because it was quite drama filled and you really got to see all the characters potential and there was a lot of magic use meaning I got to see lots of pretty animation :D\n\n
Not going to lie the relationship between Tatsuya and Miyuki did freak me out a tiny bit but I got used to it by the end so I guess it's not really a dislike just a little something that weirded me out.\n
Oh yeah and that ending also frustrated me because you suddenly get all this information about Tatsuya and its not fully explained, there is also the fact that it was ended in a cliff hanger that gave a chance for another season even though there probably wont be one.\n
I also guess again I would have like a tiny bit more back story, while there was a bit of it and hints at it it still wasn't fully explained which leaves me wondering about it and it's annoying.\n\n
SO this was one of my favourite anime so far and I hope other people love it as much as I do

Overall Score: 8/10
Story: 6/10
The story of Mahouka isn't as captivating as it could have been, but none the less it was enjoyable and the plot twists and turns kept the viewing always enjoyable. The pacing was definitely not perfect, and the arcs seemed unrelated and almost insignificant. Despite its flaws, it doesn't have any major plot holes or other problems, and is mostly enjoyable.
Art: 10/10
Some of the best art, animation and character design I have seen. All the combat scenes were gripping to watch (although mostly short) and the large character cast had varied and fitting appearances throughout the show.
Sound: 10/10
Incredible OP, and a loadof intense electronic backdrop for gripping fight scenes and such. Definitely one of the highlights of the show. \n\n
Character: 7/10\n\n
The character development was by no means bad in Mahouka, although it could have easily been better. An obvious problem is the massive cast, making major character development not a priority, or so it seems. Despite this, Tatsuya's secrets and overall overpowered-ness made the show interesting to watch, and is definitely a must-see for those who love OP MC's. However, depending on your standpoint on incest, it has the potential to make this show more or less enjoyable, even if the relationship dynamic is well done between characters.\n\n
Enjoyment: 7/10\n\n
I had fun watching this anime, but the enjoyment you get from it comes alot from the MC Tatsuya's overpowered-ness, how you take strong incest vibes, and how much the art/sound matter to you. I think most people would enjoy this show, and regardless of the points lost for the slightly-above average story, it was definitely worth the watch.

"Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei is the most disappointing thing since my son." - Mr Plinkett 
I know that Mr Plinkett never say this, but he'll if he will ever review this show.
Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei (aka The Irregular at Magic High school) is actually one of the most disappointing anime I ever watched. I started to watch the show without any expectation whatsoever, and this show still disappoints me. Almost everything in this anime make no sense whatsoever. Now shall we enter to the review?
Story: 2
One of the biggest problem with this show is the story. The premise of the show is interesting but theexecution is a total abomination. Almost nothing happens and basically everything happen in this show is only to make the MC looks awesome. This show has 3 arc and basically these arcs are like: MC-kin involved in some events, boring buildup, then something happens, Tatsuya solves it and everyone around him likes him. In most of the episodes, there'll be some very boring magic explanation nonsense going on. I know they did this to make the audience understand what's happening, but it's so boring that makes the audiences want to sleep. Tatsuya's OPness also make this show boring because he basically can solve anything. When this happen, there's no tension. There's no struggle and conflict because Tatsuya is basically God. He can solve everything.


Art: 6

The art style in this anime is honestly one of the reason I started to watched the show. But as I watching this show, the art is honestly kinda average to me. Sure the characters are beautifully draw, but the problem I have with the art is almost every characters in this show looks almost identical without their eye color and unique(kinda) hairstyle.


Sound: 5

The soundtrack is kinda the another saving grace for the show for me. Some of the songs are good but unfortunately very generic and forgettable since I have heard something similar for over hundred times.


Character: 2

This is definitely the worst part of the show. Almost very characters in this show is boring, forgettable and lack development, even for the main character. The MC, Tatsuya and Miyuki is bland and boring. Tatsuya is basically a one-dimensional Gary Stu without anything remarkable about him. Miyuki is also very annoying with all of the "I love my brother" nonsense going on. Both Tatsuya and Miyuki is boring, stoic and unrelatable. No characters in this show feels like a actual person.


Enjoyment: 2

I didn't enjoy this show. Every time I watching this show, I almost fell asleep and spending my time more on messing around with my Lego sets. 


Overall: 3

Almost everything is wrong about this show. The premise of this show is interesting, but the execution is so terrible that I presume that even myself can execute the idea of this show better. 


This is a boring and terrible show. Find better shows to watch instead of....... this.

This show is violently defended by the sea of plebs who, having unfortunately stumbled upon it early in their anime development, don't have a proper sample to compare it to. I have frequently heard that the commercial success of this show (which was actually limited in Japan) is proof of its excellence. I'm going to settle this right now. Nicki Minaj is highly successful, and Vincent van Gogh was a failure as an artist during his lifetime. However, there is no question as to which one of these two created better art. Now that that's cleared up...
Disclaimer: I apologize if this review is rather unstructured.


The irregular at magic high is lazy and commercialized. All the "interesting" dynamics in the show are taken from other, better anime. A Kuudere main character who has unbelievable hidden talents is overwhelmingly commonplace in anime. In this show however, they did change part of that formula. Overpowered MC are generally overpowered due to their overwhelming commitment to their discipline, but because of this, they are often lacking in other areas. The MC of IaMH is simply good at everything, so overwhelmingly so, that not for a moment is there the slightest bit of tension in this show. The conflict loses all it's meaning as he brushes past all obstacles with ease. Even death isn't an obstacle as he can resurrect people. The show is a never-ending series of dues ex machinas as the MC constantly uses new abilities that for some reason scale as the scope of the "conflict" increases. 

The plot has no direction what so ever and the conclusion isn't even a conclusion.The show just stops. This would be acceptable in other shows, shows that follow an episodic format or, contain separate arcs, but this show follows a linear progression. The reason this show ends this way is quite clear. The show is based on the source material (idk, if it was manga or a light novel) and the anime simply didn't last long enough to make it to the end of the source. The show suffers a great deal from pacing. Unlike truly brilliant anime, such as FMA, which effectively spread the plot across their episodes, this anime stumbles through the plot of the source.

As far as the more tangible elements, the art/sound, there isn't a whole lot to be said. The artistic "style" of the show is limited to the excessive use of softlight. This was a prominent stylistic element in anime that had already been beaten to death long before this anime was created, but not so long ago that it offers any sense of nostalgia or even long enough that we aren't still tired of it. As for the quality of the animation, it's not terrible and it's not excellent. I'd say it's "acceptable" at least in my eyes. It's certainly modern animation, containing tweens and adobe flash like elements. I'm no expert on these things but those of you who actually care about such things will probably understand what I'm referring to. The use of "lazy" animation tactics, that new technology has made it so easy to fall back on, are certainly present in this show, but not to the point where I feel the need to give them shit about it. The voice acting didn't leave much of an impression aside from the tender relationship moments between the main character and his sister. I feel they successfully enhanced the feelings they intended to with the voice acting around these moments.

As a whole, it's not like this show has nothing to offer. I mean I did watch it all the way through. There are many "things" happening in the "plot" that could be described as "entertaining" or "exciting" (sorry for all the quotes). The school genre is quite popular, and for good reason. I certainly like it, and this show has those elements. Also, for those of you who enjoy Moe little sisters, and heavily implied incestual (but never confirmed) incestual relationships, there's a lot of that. For fans of violent action anime and the whole dynamic where the OP guy pretends he's, like wimpy or something, yup got it. The point, which I hope I have established by now, is that none of it is particularly well done compared to other shows. Anime is a vast universe and if ya explore a little deeper I'm sure you'll see what I'm talking about, hopefully, even those of you who are overwhelmed by nostalgia vibes.

This was literally one of the worst anime ever. To make matters worse, it had 26 episodes. This was an incredible waste of time for not only the viewers, but whoever the hell made it. 
The story presents an interesting concept of a world controlled by this science driven magic, and then really limits it to school. So there's no real sense of adventure because it's all just academic nonsense.
The characters are terrible. No REAL personality written for them. They're just tropes of anime/manga stories plopped into a series. 8/10 % of the dialogue is meaningless and pushes the story forward in no way whatso ever. It's not even interesting. It's the over-explanation of how someone's magic works or it's just poorly timed meaningless banter about nothing at all. Biggest issue is the lack of growth in the main character. They downplay him as an underdog, despite the fact that he's not in any way shape or form and then just let the story continue down the same path which is "no one can beat this guy so lets just put him in danger and watch him win easily every-time".

A summary of this anime in a few words would be this:
It's pretty much magic replacing live weaponry as the tools for the world. A super OP main character with a splash of brother sister love add in some magic combat and you get this anime. Oh and most people who are magicians are badasses. 
Now that I've gotten the super quick summary done. I'll do the main focus of my review. The anime itself focuses around Tatsuya (older brother) and Miyuki (sister). These two have a powerful bond for each other and they continue to make everyone of their friends uncomfortable as they displayaffection for each other in public. 


(I do not do spoilers btw or at least I try not to.)


Tatsuya as I said is completely over powered. He only has one setting it seems. Extremely calm. Nothing seems to rattle him as more and more drastic situations arise. Oh and don't mess with Miyuki. He will FIND YOU and KILL YOU. 


Miyuki is the loving sister who adores her big brother. She's also extremely powerful. Her favorite spells are usually ice based. She's also really beautiful. 


The focus becomes them going to this magic high school where magicians develop their skills for later on in life. Due to testing Tatsuya winds up as a second class student (a weed) and Miyuki is first class (a flower). 


There are three different phases that go down in this anime throughout the 26 episodes. One focusing on the school. On focusing on this all schools sporting event and lastly...all out war. That is all I can say. The last one was especially gripping with all the action that started to come out. 


I did feel there were some unanswered questions from this anime when I finished it. Like the strange purple haired guy Zhou and what his true deal is.


I finish by saying. If i haven't convinced you to watch it why not try it out. If you love OP Main Characters and pretty bad ass side characters and romantic situations...plus some brother-sister love fest. This anime will be for you! If over powered main characters aren't your thing maybe watching for the side characters would be a focus.

This is not your average magic school show. The show attempts to blend magic and technology together to present a more refined take on the magic genre. 
The story is centered around the Shiba siblings as they attend a magic high school. Instead of fighting monsters and making the world safe, the show focuses on the school and the activities of the school such as tournaments and internal strife. Additionally, the show is never episodic with all episodes tying into one of the three story arcs. This maybe be off putting to some viewers who prefer definitive start/stop moments or villain of the week shows.
Artis done by studio Madhouse and is very good. Magic spells are well done and flow smoothly. (I'm not a stickler for art details so there's not much to say.)


Sound is good and varied. Openings and endings are enjoyable to listen to even if they probably won't fit into a playlist. The show has transition music between scenes and various tracks for sporting events and battles. This keeps reused the assets low and adds to the overall enjoyment. 


The characters are the high point of the show for me. All of the major and minor characters are given some amount of screen time. Most of this involves analyzing a recent event or a person's actions that reveals each character's perceptions and personality. This creates a wide option of characters to use in a scene without forcing them into specific situations. It has to be mentioned that the Shiba siblings are an odd couple and often flirt with incest, much to the dismay of their classmates. While never actually having a incestuous relationship, their behavior can be objectionable. 


Enjoyment depends on the viewers preferences. If you enjoy desperate battles and clothing inexplicably melting from magic power; this isn't the show for you. Magic is explained and enhanced through science. Which means sometimes lengthy explanations. This slows the pace down making battles more calculated and decisive. Additionally, the siblings are incredibly OP. Overall power is something determined at birth in this series, so training montages or power growth is not present. Because of this viewers could feel unsatisfied at the lack of challenge facing the characters.


Overall, it is a very good show. It won't win points for riveting action or over the top flashy sequences, but viewers who stick around for story and characters won't be disappointed.
