This show was ok it was not bad it was not brilliant it was just ok. I watched this show assuming it would be one of the best slices of bread you can get from the anime culture as some people tend to talk about it a bit, however I didn't find the hype of it most of the time.
Story 5/10:
The story has a cool concept a future where the world relies on magic high schools to train magicians for war. The story is a bunch of arcs the first being an introduction to the 20 or more characters in the first 2 to 4episode. This one section of the story focused on introducing so many characters that is took over most of the first few episodes. The second arc is a magic competition between magic schools. This part would have been a lot more interesting if eight episodes of it did not feel like filler. The last arc which I will not say for spoiler reasons was actually good and worth watching. The series did have some epic moments that I thought where pretty awesome however most of those do not happen for the second half of the series.


Art 10/10: 


This anime had some of the most beautiful animation I seen in an anime. This includes the magic animations and the animations for effects like fire and ice. There are some 3D animations as well which where done pretty well. The only problem I have is some of the censoring in certain scenes where stuff gets really violent however I cant say anymore about this with out spoiling the show so I will leave it at that for the art.


Sound 7/10: 


There was no music other then the openings that really got to me. The usual background music is usually instrumental while the other half of the music is a woman singing really fast while rock rythms play.


Character 6/10:


I mentioned how the first arc was pretty much introducing 20 characters, the problem with this is that you tend to easily forget that many people very quick. They do try to develop them later but as the viewer you would not really get to attached to character unless they do something memorable right after they are introduced. When I ever watch a anime I tend to remember the names of 90% of the characters but for this show I cant. The good news is that there where some characters that I liked but that was only in the second half of the show. 


I want to talk about the main character Tatsuya who you can call pretty much a god considering how OP he is. I tend to really like the OP characters but this guy its complicated. He is literally in my top five most OP characters  but that is all there is to his character. He is metaphorically a blank slate that has been drawn on slightly and given the powers of god. He is set up to be a flunky in the school but he can do in reality the most metal things possible. Any thing interesting about or gives him any character like his past is thrown out the window leaving the slate uncompleted.  There was a lot of opportunities to make his character more likable but they blew it. 



Enjoyment 5/10:


The last arch was really good but the slow pace of the competition arch really reduced the enjoyment factor out of the show. 



Overall 6/10

The irregular at magic high school, better known as Mahouka, is a well produced anime. It's a much more standard Shounen anime than I first thought, and you could easily place it with recent anime such as Tokyo Ravens or Accel World.
Good:
+ Magic system is interesting. So broken that it's not.
+ Large cast of characters.
+ Decently paced. Doesn't drag on to fill the animation budget.
+ Drama is kept to a reasonable level.
+ Characters aren't dying left and right.
+ Leaves room for a second, and/or third season.
+ Relatively unique concept of magic
Bad:
- Shiba siblings aren't well explained nor explored.
- Characters aren't dying left and right.
- Magician's"mana" limits are ill-defined. \n\n
Ugly:\n
-- It's a standard Shounen series in disguise.\n
-- Haters seem to really hate characters that are completely overpowered to the point of nigh-invincibility. (I say this only because Tokyo Ravens and Mahouka have a score difference of .09, but the top reviews for Mahouka are 7-3-5-7, and Tokyo Raven's top reviews are 8-8-7-8.) Don't people realize that main character's lives are only on the line at season endings? \n\n
Again, Mahouka is a standard Shounen. It doesn't have a mind blowing plot, it's characters aren't getting slaughtered by the dozens.  What really interests quite a few people is the premise. Sadly, the premise isn't the complete driving force of the anime. However, magic in the anime obeys it's own laws. And by it obeying it's own laws, I mean its overpowered in every aspect, especially those that are figureheads.\n\n
Speaking of overpowered, that's where our main characters come in. Shiba Tatsuya, and Shiba Miyuki. Technically they're the main characters, but they're quite dull. One is practically soulless, and the other has a Big Brother complex. Neither are particularly interesting, raw power is where they stop. \n\n
The redeeming aspect of the show is the large cast outside of the Shiba siblings. The student council is interesting, the Nine Schools participants are solid, and it just feels like many of them are people.\n\n
I do recommend Mahouka, mostly because of it's magic. If you've done programming, it's like programming with physics, so some interesting concepts come up. The characters are likable enough, and there's enough action, plus drama doesn't swallow up the show. I'm looking forward to the next season

Overall impression:
Those series have some sort of a slow and relaxing feeling to them (despite having violent scenes), and most of the time can be described as "okay". Aside from few episodes near the end, where this anime tried to be something that didn't make much sense, most of the episodes are "alright". They aren't dull, aren't annoying, but aren't very exciting either.
Characters:
Main character is overpowered. Due to his personality it isn't annoying (because he's just very strong, but not perfect), but in those few episodes near the end there are few somewhat ridiculous scenes.
Most characters are somewhat faceless, although there were few interesting ones.For example, I found Chiba Erika interesting. Interactions between characters usually are somewhat "flat", although there were few scenes that were somewhat enjoyable.


Story:

Someone spent a LOT of time creating theory of magic for this setting. Most of the time anime looks like a long overview of the world with magic in it. That's where the anime works. However, when this anime tries to get more dramatic, the story stops being very believable. Over course of story, anime picks few important topics, and then sorta just forgets about them, apparently after being distracted by main character's power. 


Story consists of multiple arcs and they're all very long.


Art:

Nothing outsanding there. Character faces are standard triangular low-detailed faces that are used in the modern anime often. The art style doesn't have any unique personality to it, although I found few side-characters interesting visually. The anime uses anime-stylized CG models on some occasions, most of the time for background crowds, but in those few weaker episodes near the end I mentioned, there are scenes with obviously not hand-drawn objects and characters, and they don't look too well in movement.


Sound:

Music in those series is disappointing. Nothing in soundtrack stands out, and on few occasions it gets slightly annoying and somewhat disruptive to the dialogue. 


Bottom line:

I'm not sure if I'd recommend it. Due to slow pacing and methodical explanation of the world and its magic, it can be a decent show to kill time (most of the time it isn't dull or boring, but not exciting either), but ultimately there aren't many memorable things about it.

I would like to write a short review to provide my opinion of this anime.
To begin, this review is based purely on the Anime itself as I have not read the Light Novels. Furthermore while I will avoid spoilers, I cannot provide a review without some references to the story.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Should you watch this anime?
---------------------------------------------------------------------
- The protagonist is powerful, so if you want to watch a power creep punctuated with hard fights this is not the anime for you.
- If I were to categorise this anime I would say that it is a story anime with battle undertones, so it would be best suited toviewers willing to explore the universe.

- If you like that moment in animes where the cast see the protagonist's new power and are impressed/in awe, you will probably like this.


So, I would strongly recommend this, but feel free to read on if that doesn't convince you.


2. Some analysis on the anime.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

The main aspect of the story that some will hate is that the main character is powerful. While he is only evaluated as a 'weed' or 'irregular' when entering school we discover that this is due to the assessment being unsuited to his skills. The story does not see the protagonist power up, or train to overcome problems since he is alrady more than capable, instead we are gradually introduced to what his abilities are, how and why he has them and where he fits into the universe.


As for the cast in general. They are brought to life by great voice acting, artwork, and their interactions throughout the show, with occasional references to their past to help explain certain traits. There is very little use of flashbacks or timeskips to explain the characters which means that it will take longer for each character to be explained through the story, but since you don't get pulled out to see the past, you are much better immersed within the events.

Overall I found that the supporting cast felt like a group of individuals I could really get behind, and found myself remembering names, traint and backgrounds much more than other anime's.


The story while being critisised by some reviews, was actually highly interesting and well developed. The integration of magic as a science and the detail that the show goes into to explain it was new and interesting. The gradual discoveries about the lead characters background provides an underlying storyline. While the individual story arc's work well to introduce the charaters and further the backstory.

The progression of the story is primarily based on dialogue, though it didn't feel slow as the interaction between the characters was often valuable in either explaining the universe, story or providing insight into a charater.


3. Overall opinion.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

I loved it and have now watched the series multiple times.


I tend to get emotionally invested in whatever I watch, so I love it when things go well. As such I found it refreshing to have a main character who didn't get his ass kicked in every fight.


The fights while largely one sided were interesting and displayed a balance between what Tatsuya could do, what he shouldn't do, and what the cast saw him do. Which provided a pleasant change from the common theme of repetative struggle and training.


For me the second best bits in the anime are the times we discover more about the lead characters, with the best bits being the interactions with the cast where they gradually discover how powerful Tatsuya is, and his position outwith the school.


---------------------------------------------------------------------

-I would also mention this is not an anime with much 'fan service' though some dialogue will hint at such things, and there is some infrequent mild nudity.

-The show does use some hits at incest, though this is purely in dialogue and mostly to embarrass members of the cast for humerous effect.

-There is violence, mostly gore free with rare scenes of blood as part of dismemberment.

I decided to watch this anime because I once looked up best anime fight scenes on YouTube and found one from this anime. One of the best fight scenes I've ever seen, good enough to convince me to start an entire 26-episode show. However, some caveats.
After seeing majesties like FMAB, Code Geass, Hunter x Hunter (2011), etc. this was disappointing. The relationship between Tatsuya and his sister is interesting, although a bit unnerving in that Miyuki loves her brother as more than a brother. Still, the fight scenes (magic) are good and the concept of building a society around magic as a technology is intriguing.The sound wasn't anything special, kinda annoying actually when listening to it separately. The character development of Tatsuya, an insanely powerful magician, is pretty awesome, although not as awesome as Ichigo's or Naruto's. It was pretty enjoyable, but not addicting. I would only recommend this if you are interested in the high school genre, magic with magicians genre, or are a serious anime viewer and want to see them all.

Alright, so right now you are probably thinking: "Hey, isn't this that show where the main protagonists are siblings and in love with each other and there's incest and sh*t?". And I can't deny it, you are right to some degree. But there's also so much more to this show that a lot of people seem to just gloss over, so in this review, I'll be attempting to explain why I found Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei to be as enjoyable as I did.
Now, a very important thing to note when it comes to this show, is that it's not for everybody. If you are thetype of person that absolutely hates overpowered characters, turn around right now, because this show isn't for you. In order to fully enjoy Mahouka, you as a viewer have to come to terms with the fact that our main protagonist, Tatsuya, is literally God in human form. This guy doesn't know the definition of the word "lose", as he has never lost in anything ever. This is the type of guy that goes 32-0-12 in League of Legends and singlehandedly carries your entire team to victory like its nothing. As long as you can accept the fact that Tatsuya = God, you are good to go.


The second point I'd like to touch on is the topic of "incest" in this show. Our godlike protagonist just so happens to have a little sister, who (of course) is madly in love with him. Now, where other shows like to use the excuse of "they are not related by blood", this show wears its incest coat with pride, clearly stating that they are biological siblings and still in love. I'm not gonna lie, this kinda rubbed me the wrong way initially, as I just found their relationship to be incredibly weird, especially considering that they are LEGIT SIBLINGS, AND THIS KIND OF LOVE GOES WAY BEYOND THAT WHICH IS NORMAL FOR SIBLINGS. But after getting into it, you start to realize that their incestuous relationship really doesn't mean a whole lot in the larger scope of things, as there are only a few scenes in the entire show where the creator really points out the fact that yes, they are siblings, and yes, they are indeed in love. It's really up to you whether you think this kind of relationship is okay or not, and whether you are willing to tolerate it.


However, where this show really starts to shine is in its worldbuilding. You see, magic in this world is more akin to that of science than the traditional wizards and spells. Each magic "spell" is built up sorta like a mathematic formula, where long components have to be correctly put together in order to perform actual working magic. Its obvious that the creator of this show really wanted you to learn about his type of magic, as a good deal of time is spent explaining the different magic spells and how they work. This can get quite heavy at times, with exposition-heavy dialogue that carries on for tens of minutes just to explain what it was you just saw. If this kind of thing turns you off, I would not recommend picking up this show, as you will quite simply be bored out of your mind.


TL;DR: Now, with all of that said, I still found Mahouka to be a genuinly enjoyable show. Its entertainment value is simply through the roof, and I often found myself thinking "damn, that was so badass". In a world full of weak male protagonists that needs to be protected, Tatsuya really stands out as the "alpha dog", as he is pretty much the human incarnation of the phrase "1v5 me irl bro". If you are looking for a deep show with rich psychological value and philosophical thoughts, you are better off elsewhere. But if you are looking for a show where you get to see a human God fight terrorists and other threats with magic, this is exactly the thing for you.

The Irregular at Magic High School. As the title is relatively long, it can mislead people into thinking it's one of those garbage anime *cough-ICouldn'tBecomeaHeroSoIReluctantlyDecidedtoGetaJob-cough*, but that sure as  hell didn't stop me from giving it a shot. And honestly, when I started watching it the first time around on Netflix (which, by the way, is scheduled to remove it from netflix entirely in about...less than an hour at the time of writing this, give or take), I didn't exactly hate it, but I wasn't too fond of it either. If I could remember why, I'd talk about it...but I can't, so...sorry.
Anyway, at thetime, I left off at the dead-beginning of episode 10, and didn't get back around to finishing the series until literally 3 days ago, at the time of writing this. The only real reason I finished the show this time around was because of the removal that is about to happen on January 1st from Netflix. In other words, I felt pressured to watch it. And when I DID finally finish it, I came out of it speaking this quote, "Not too bad."\n
The first episode began by being rather blunt. And this was a consistent pattern I noticed throughout the large majority of the show. More often than not, people like Tatsuya Shiba will be like (and I'm paraphrasing here), "Get to the point, spare me the details." And while, yes, I get that it's the whole point of his character, it just made him and many other characters so very bland for the main protagonists of the show.\n
The plot revolves around Tatsuya and Miyuki Shiba, a brother and sister who both got through their entrance exams for Magic High, but Miyuki, the self-proclaimed "weaker" of the pair, ended up getting a far higher score than her older brother. As such, Tatsuya is put into a category of students called weeds, whereas Miyuki gets to be a bloom, and student rep. Beyond that, however, the ending was subpar, at best. The most emotion I got out of it was the final discussion between Masaki Ichijo and his closest partner, Shinkurou Kichijouji, and even then, I was barely fazed.\n
Tiny spoiler: Even if Tatsuya was very by-the-books, his inevitable bromance with Masaki Ichijo was actually really interesting to see, especially considering the fact that Masaki had a major crush on Tatsuya's sister. It was also pretty cool seeing Tatsuya being so accepting of the relationship between the three of them. I was initially expecting the two young men to have a blatant hero-villain sort of setup to them, not much unlike that of Vash & Knives in Trigun. I was happy to see I was wrong. Not that it's a bad plot twist, but it would've felt like they stole the plot somewhat from Trigun.\n
In summary,  I felt like this anime was enjoyable, but sooooo bland.

This is great anime, if you want a strong main character. The only real problem is that the anime progresses very slowly. So slow that a snail would like sports car next to it. Also there are hints of an incestous relationship between the 2 main characters, though one could bear it to a certain degree, it is just plain weird. So if don't like stuff like that, this anime is not for you. Also this anime sometimes has a harem feel to it too.
So, my recommendation is to watch this if you want a strong protagonist, good for you.
