There was this school that I really wanted to get into.  Around the time the decision of that school was coming out, I was watching Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei (Mahouka from now on).  After around five episodes, I thought to drop it.  However, because I really wanted to go to this school, I made a promise with myself to God: if I got into the school of my dreams, I would watch the rest of Mahouka.  I know, I know, that’s pretty dumb; why the hell would God care about me watching some random anime?  As it turns out, Igot in.  Because I didn’t want to incur the heavenly wrath on myself or anyone I care about, I decided to watch through the rest of Mahouka.  After finishing, I realized that this actually was a fair trade between God and me.  Watching this show was actually a huge price to pay.


Honestly, I would rather do work than watch Mahouka.


The show has good production value, as expected of Madhouse, one of the best studios in the game.  However, not even Madhouse can salvage the trash story.  Mahouka depicts Tatsuya during his time at First High School, a high school for magic users.  He’s been put into the second level, “no talent” student pool.  However, as it turns out, Tatsuya is perfect, in every sense of the word.  He gets all the girls, is wicked smart, has the best physical fitness and combat ability, and is crazy gifted in magic (despite what the show might say in narration or dialogue).


At first, the story sounds pretty cool.  After all, who wants to keep watching stories about people rising from the bottom to become number one through determination?  Some variety is always welcome.  However, as a result of this characterization of Tatsuya, the story wrote itself into a hole.


There is literally no tension in Mahouka.  At the beginning of each conflict, the villains are introduced, and they always look stupid.  Looks might be deceiving, but in Mahouka that’s not the case; all the villains actually are stupid and weak.  Not only that, they are so one-dimensional that it’s impossible to sympathize with any of them.  The result is that conflict does not actually exist in this show.  A “problem” shows up, Tatsuya is dispatched, problem is solved easily.  


If there is no conflict, there is no reason to care.  Terrorists?  Walk in the park.  Mafia?  LOL.  All are powerless before Tatsuya.  What the writer could have done to fix the story would have been to create a problem that Tatsuya could struggle against.  That way, we could feel tension.  That way, we could watch episodes without falling asleep.  That way, this show wouldn’t suck enough to be a price that a deity would ask for in exchange for a wish.


Why doesn’t the writer do this?  It’s because Tatsuya was created to be the pinnacle of wish-fulfillment.  He has to win everything, every girl has to fall for him, and every problem must be solved by him.  While being perfect, Tatsuya also has no personality to speak of.  Tatsuya, in other words, is a slot where the audience can insert itself and pretend they are him.  Creating a problem he cannot solve would contradict the entire mission of this show.  The writer doesn’t create a good villain because he cannot.


The fact that a show completely devoid of substance managed to attain this level of acclaim is alarming.  We need to worry about the people that like this stuff; maybe their lives aren’t very fulfilling.  If this describes you, go do things with people!  It’ll be fun, I promise.


Finally, the irony has not been lost on me.  I mentioned that God was the motivation for watching Mahouka.  I also described Tatsuya as the perfect being.  So maybe Tatsuya is God?  Maybe he rewarded me for watching his show.  We’ll never know, but just to be careful, I didn’t say anything bad about Tatsuya in this review…just in case.

I really enjoyed watching The Irregular At Magic High School, Mainly because of the characters in the series. The main protagonist in the series is one of my favourite male anime characters because of his emotionless personality and unbeatable ability. The series has a lot of action sequences and is very enjoyable to watch. The use of magic in this series is very unique on how they use it with "Magic Sequences" to power weapons. The soundtrack of the series is also something to admire, along with the art style, clothing and magic sequence designs. If you enjoy magic battles in schools with school magicrankings you would enjoy this anime, I personally did. \n

This is what amounts to the decay of human capacity, with the funding that the studio had for this anime they could've made something so much better, hell just GIVE the money to Bones so they could make a sequel to the original Soul Eater. All I'll say is get ready because im on a roll today. (SPOILER ALERT THERE ARE MANY BELOW!)
So when I started watching this anime I was a bit turned off by the art style itself, the main characters are hardly memorable in the way that they look and sound. After I put a couple of episodes under my belt Ibegan to see how bad this was going to become so as a result I turned not to expect much from it and I'll say that from that point on, the show actually surprised me with how good it was in comparison to my expectationsSo let's start from the beginning of the anime, at episode 1 they show how magic originated and the first episode as is common for most anime is just backstory, alright from episodes 2-6 this is when things just become monotonous, they drone on and on about magic sequences and different forms of using magic and the main character's pistols being special and how all this stuff is going on, but in truth... They don't actually explain what you need in order to completely understand the show.\n
*this is a part where I'd like to mention I'm doing one arc of the story at a time, the first So resuming,being the Competition Arc the second being the Thesis Arc.\n
From there on out the story falls into a competition with the other Magic High Schools (nine of them total.) and this arc in general just serves no purpose whatsoever except for maybe some additional character development that in general is completely useless since the character development is HORRENDOUS in this anime. all-in-all I had fun with it but it's very incoherent so it's a general no-go.

Very interesting story. From the onset, focus is on the 2 main characters of the story. Story slowly unfolds and author slowly brings in more depth to the characters. Shrouded in mystery, it makes you want to follow and find out more about the characters and their background.
Most importantly, it's easy to see the the author has brought in many facets and issues people face in society today into the plot - discrimination, struggles of the lower classes, equality, terrorism, animosity between countries among other things. 
But not a very big fan of their brother-sister love though.

So I'll make this a  short review. As a review showed, this is not for everyone, if you like detailed dialogue heavy story (thought there is some action too) and op MC's then this show is for you. Thought I recommend to be concentrated when you watch this show, because it may be confusing at times, I still have a lot of questions after finishing the show and after watching the series, i felt a bit unsatisfied at the end, I still liked the setting of the show enough for me to watch it fully. Also I liked the godtsuya / Miyuki sister brothercomplex (gave me couple of laughs). Art was pretty good, music was normal, thought I like the first intro, characters were not bad, but the story and plot plus delveloppement was a bit confusing for me, since I wasn't too concentrated when I was watching this  show. Overall 6/10.

This series is about 2 siblings enrolling in a magic high school, with the brother having a complicated background and the sister having a complicated feelings for her brother. Instead of calling him onii-chan like any normal imoutos out there, she called him onii-sama with full respect and obedience. 
She never calls her brother "baka" or flying kicking her brother like those hordes of tsundere imoutos out there. So it make me think that her brother must be a no-brainer, breast-groping, skirt-peeking, panty-sniffer, onsen-peeker pervert who have no other purpose than making this series into a full-blown ecchi series.
But I couldn't be more wrong, becausehe is a genius, cool, dependable but can be cold and unfriendly most of the time but knows how to avoid others from feeling offended by his superiority in knowledge and skills.


I have watched a lots of ecchi series, so personally I want to find a series where the male protagonist who is actually strong and capable of great things on his own instead of just relaying on his harems to boost his power and occasionally by unintentionally molesting them on daily basis. XD

I like how the female characters in this series have their own preference to the guys they like instead of all the girls in the school is crazy over the lead male protagonist like they were subjected to mind control of some sort.


So, after finished watching this series I can proudly say that I got what I want. Even though the 1st half of the series is kinda boring (especially the girl's competion), but as soon as the REAL VILLAIN makes their appearance, the story become more fun with more fight scenes.

Fanservice-wise, this series have little of it. No onsen episode, no beach bikini episode watsoever! Or did I missed it somehow? Nevermind that.


About the art, which I rated 6 because it failed to amaze me but it is still acceptable. The character design is okay but the surrounding environment, weapon design, the clothing design and the fight scene graphics is kinda LAME and BLAND. When I finally get to see the suit Tatsuya wear in action, I instantly recalled the CRYSIS suits. Compared to that, Tatsuya's suit look like shit to me except that it can fly and and not from alien origin.


I totally looking forward for 2nd season and hopefully some OVA containing a summer beach bikini episode will be released. The girls in this series have a lots of "potential" that only a bikini episode can truly  unleash.

TL;DR I don't like this series, and it makes me mad, because every piece of the series is something I enjoy. Something about the way it's told just leaves me behind and and confused. 
Honestly, I loved the art style here. I loved the glow effects. I liked the style for humans & hair. Designs were standard 'what I want to see in my anime' fare. I enjoyed and was very interested in the premise - from magic, to the world, to the school, to the character's personalities (even, and indeed especially, the OP Tatsuya. I find people who are 'on a whole other level'interesting, sue me.), motivations, & challenges. Opening and ending themes are going to be on my playlist for a looong time to come!


But in the viewing?


It's really flat and dull. Towards the last 10 episodes, I'm exceedingly confused and lost about what's going on. I can't tell if I'm just not picking up on a ton of 'foreshadowing' or 'developing' they're doing between the lines, or if it's really all just filler actions and dialogue that add to nothing. 


I want to finish it because I'm just 3 and a half episodes from the end, and when I think about the premise and appearance of the show, it seems like a no brainer to do it. But watching it is a chore.


I paused the middle of my episode to come right this review in an effort to 'take a break' without closing the tab of the episode. 


Very disappointing. On paper, this should've been one of my favorite shows. 


Maybe someday I'll try the light novels after a few more years of Japanese study.

This anime for me was one of the most refreshing and great anime i have seen in a long while. Why ,  because of the characters , the music and the story makes such an interesting combination that it feels new and interesting. First of all a character that i will admit is kinda OP i still loved it because of it. A Main character that start of as a great at what he does is so rare in anime that its sometimes a discovery in itself to find it. What has also made me like this anime alot is that i read theoriginal Novel which i will say gave me a greater understanding and also a greater love for the anime. The more i watched it the more addicted it became for me. And at the end the great music which made my body move as i watched the anime and exhilarated battles. 


Though i will say that if long explanation and slightly incestous pointers isnt your things i wouldnt say this is for everyone. And for some you might feel like something is missing or left out.  


So if you dont like long explanation , have a high limit on moral and hate when things are missing then it might not be for you. But if you love battles that almost make your body move in tune with the music. And like that the main character dont slip up on every turn until he finaly gets strong in the final episode then this deffinetly is an anime to watch. This is an anime which will show how great every character can be from start to finish but might leave you with a question or two but dont worry every anime has its ups and downs but i decided to review this because it had too many ups that the downs couldnt really strike it down much.

[WARNING:May contain spoilers]
Well Mahouka was a mixed package for me,but still enjoyable enough to encourage me to  finish the whole series.So now into the details:
Story:5
The concept is very basic, with the whole underdog thing.However, there were some plot points which I liked, such as using the discrimination theme to fuel an entire arc emphasizing on real life problems.Also it nice to see that the MC works behind the scenes rather than always being in midst of the action.
Okay now about the bad sides of the plot, the pacing in the first episodes are horribly slow, I was forcing myself through most of the storybecause people kept telling me it gets better after episode 16, which it did and that's why I could finish it.Then there was the lack of backstory I wanted  to know why Shiba was like this seeing as they showed glimpses of his past.Finally the use of jargon, they keep bantering about activation sequences and other stuff I could barely understand.They didn't explain anything, they thought the audience was supposed know this for some reason, All I understood is they use magic.


Art:9

As usual madhouse provides spectacular art and animation.The fight scenes were pretty good.

The art was very colorful which was good to look at.I had only two problems with the art and animation the inconsistent animation and the few generic character design


Sound:7

I paid little attention to the soundtrack but it was good and the openings were fine not one of the most memorable soundtracks.


Character:6

The character development is very lacking though everyone has their unique characteristic.The villains are complete disappointment the only one that found intriguing had little focus(Zhou).There are some good characters and some with their separate character arcs.But the main problem was with the lead Shiba (spoiler) I don't know why he's is a mindless husk,I needed to know him in order to sympathize with him,but I did have a little sympathy for him seeing his discrimination and pain.


Enjoyment:7

I enjoyed the occasionally good humor,Shiba proving his better than those who looked down on him ,and the character chemistry


Well my review was more on the negative side but seeing the faults in Mahouka it needed to be,Well that's it folks see ya(cliche goodbye)

Warning This review may contain spoilers.
First impressions, so we got an underdog story in the world where magic and science have fused into one. So this sounds interesting enough what could possibly go wrong?
Story, 3/10
In a world where magic and science come together. Where a massive world war took place Which was not going to show you because that might be too  complex to show and care about good storytelling, How about instead we show you the adventures of a two siblings a brother named Tatsuya and his sister Miyuki going through magic high school, Which for some reason has a caste system inplace. That puts you in different classes depending on your magical ability instead of your actual skill or talent you may have. Basically what happens is are sibling duo take this test with the Little sister ending up in top classes known as the bloom with her older brother Tatsuya who is the main character being put in the weed cast. Who surprisingly possesses skills and knowledge that reach way higher levels than 99% of his  classmates even those who are bloom class are nothing more than mere pebbles when compared to him.

So basically this try's to be some sort of underdog story that also trying to do a critic of some of the negatives of human society. Which on paper sounds like a good idea. But it falls apart when your main character is overpowered as all fuck and your content is about as shallow as a kiddie pool, Like why would you have a caste system in a  magic high school where everyone comes from powerful magical family’s or have skills way above the average joe. So any student that would be going to this school  have already proven  that there a cut above everyone else and also if the goals of these schools are to train new magicians as weapons and etc then why wouldn’t they just go like full  Meritocracy and just have the students  compete against one another  in various fields to find the best students and those who performed well get awarded and have certain privileges, that would have been better and far more effective for training  the next generations  of magicians. Instead of my magical ability better than yours reee so I going to be a one Dimensional asshole towards you. 

And to top it all off add in a whole cluster fuck of overused tropes and clichés from light novels In Till it becomes an unbelievable cringe-fest of epic proportions. But if you want to know the story contains I am happy to tell you. The story from about 5-6 episodes is about this school class system bullshit which at face value was kind of interesting and thought-provoking when I first watched it when I was first getting into anime.But when I stepped back and actually thought about it.I realized that the conflict is shallow. And that basically the same thing for every theme this show try's to do.

At face value it all good and Dandy But when you look back and think about it.You start seeing these big holes in logic But back to the story. The rest of the story basically just, terrorist Attucks, school torments and a bunch of random shit that just isn't interesting or has any tension to it.Especially Because the main character can pretty much kill any threat in an in a split second without much effort. But To make my point more clear there is one scene where he gets shot straight in the heart and their blood everywhere. And I don't need to tell you that even if you live past a gunshot to the heart which is pretty much is unlikely to happen. You would basically die from blood loss if you didn't get to the hospital in time. What happens is that his sister gets rid of one of the limiters that holding his power back and he gets back up no problem at all even with the blood loss and during the end, he just goes full This is a featured article. Click here for more information. Page semi-protected Listen to this article Jesus-kun mode and blows up an  entire naval fleet in a few seconds so in honesty this show story has failed in almost every aspect it done. Calling it generic as an insult would probably be the understatement of the century. Even for an anime based on a light novel, it's horrid. it’s almost like this series just wants to test the waters to see how little effort people you have to put into your series while at the same time making tons of money from your bottom of the barrel trash.

The only positive I can actually list is that I think the setting is interesting. With how the magic works, the magic families and there politics and the how modern science and magic has become to this one thing.  Like the idea of magic and technology merging into this one thing is really interning idea and the whole idea of these magic clans, governments, or other terrorist factions battling each over to get a leg up over one another. That makes the world and the politics feel way more organic and gives the series some actual depth if they actuality focused on it.  But even that can't save face fully when it doesn't go in as deep as it should as what this series is adapted is mostly focusing on school bullshit and when it comes to the magic system they throw so much techno babe at you. That it really hard to get a proper footing when you’re trying to wrap your head around this magic system. What would have been really cool is that instead of this high school bullshit, they could have turned this series into some epic global political thriller with various organizations trying to one-up each other similar to darker than black. That would have been cooler and way better than what we got.



Characters, 3/10

The main character Tatsuya is bland as toast with no emotions because his family literally took his emotions away except for slight protective feeling for his little sister, basicity his family turned him into a sociopath. Which could have been interesting if they were using his character exploring and talking about the inhumanity of such individuals or what makes them tick and guides their moral compass. That would have been cool and deep, but no all we get is another soulless self-insert who kind of a nice-ish guy despite his sociopath "testacy’s".  At least the show took the time to explain why it happened, But even the reasoning behind it was stupid. Basically, the main character had his emotions taken away from him Because from what is shown so far is that his family thought he would turn ageist the clan and kill them all of them because he was very powerful even as a young boy.  And I guess if you’re a young child that is basicity a ticking time bomb of magical power and emotions then it would make sense why his family would want to try to get that under control or at least prevent the possibility to him losing control of his power and going themo nuclear on everyone asses. 

But the logic and reasoning behind it still fall apart, when you consider if he no emotions. That would means his mind is mostly running on a logos based  thought process correct, ok  So what would actually happen if it became logical to turn around and kill his entire clan in order to reach a certain  goal and  he has no emotions and dosnt even have a bound with 99% of  his family because of what they did to him and also the fact they treat him like dog shit, (even though he is handsome, smart, owns a very successful business on the side and is highly trained in various combat skills.)                                           

Bottom line is that his clan are imbecile because if they thought taking his emotions away would make him easy to control and he never turns ageist them despite how they treat him they are dead wrong. Because of there such a thing as psychopaths/ sociopath who in laymen terms have every little emotions or empathy for others at all and have no problem killing people at all. and even though Tatsuya isn’t really malicious in most of his actions. You cant forget the fact that in this series alone he has killed a lot of people with zero fucks given, grated most of the time it was in self-defense or he was protecting his sister, but who to say he won’t turn around and do the same thing to his family. Also if he has no emotions then why the fuck does he actually invest time In combat training or anything for that matter. Because he would have to have some sort of motivation or passion to do that. Which he doesn't because he's a robot that will never become a real boy.


Also his younger sister Miyuki has to be by far the most annoying character in the whole show. Even more annoying than the one-dimensional assholes that populate the show like flies. She is basically then the only thing the Main character has a slight emotional attachment to and for some reason she has a brother complex. Which doesn't really make much sense because we find out that in the past even she treated him like shit in till awhile ago. Plus he has been an emotionless robot for most of his life. So Whatever speck of humanity that was in him is already long gone. I mean she would probably have a deeper relationship with a teddy bear than her robot of a brother.


The side characters are pretty much hollow shells with no personality or anything interesting about them. They are basically just so one note. There like background characters. Because every time I watch this show I have to remind myself that these characters actually exist. And when they talk about themselves or some sort of backstory. Its  like for me who the fuck are you again.


Art, 7/10

The animation was good, backgrounds are kind of average.

It has some very bright colors which help add to the magic ability’s that go on in the series It has some of the c.g.i Animation and considering japan tack record for CGI in anime this is quite imperative that it looks nice and doesn't clash with the 2d animation  The art style of generic as fuck.The characters design look so plain and hollow. It basically a copy and paste from most light novel series. 


Sound, 5/10

The op and ending songs I don't give a fuck about in the lest. the ost is ok as a whole. Nothing really good or bad about it. But I think it's ok to check it out. The ost was done by Taku Iwasaki who has done the ost for soul taker and black butler for example. When it comes to voice acting I felt everyone did an ok job distaste how bad this series is and the dialog is dry as toast.



Enjoyment, 2/10

Enjoyment or lack of enjoyment, in this case, I found nothing really enjoyable about this show. I found it a very soulless watch. it is one of worse shows  I have watched in my life And I would put this show in my top ten worse anime I have watched list. I am pretty sure I would have enjoyed this show more if there was personally or spirit put behind it, because of the world and some of the elements this show was slightly interesting. But it's hard to care when it every clear that the people to did this show had a gun pointed at their head.



Overall,3/10 

There is no way in hell I would recommend this to anyone under any circumstances. Even my worse enemy's I wouldn't show this trash to them. If your new to anime don't waste your time on this show, Because you’re going to look back and realize your wasted time. And that you could have watched someone else that you probably would have enjoyed ten times better than this. My advice just pretends this doesn't exist, Hell even madhouse who did the anime for this pretends it doesn't exist as well. The only reason I can see people watching this is that the music is passable and the visuals look very nice. Because story and characters are pretty much non-existent.

If you like the ideas this series has your better of watching failed knight, a certain magical index or strike the blood.

I really liked this anime, but I understand that it is not for everyone. So what did I like about this that other people may not like?
1. Shiba Tatsuya, the protagonist: If you do not connect with this character, you have little chance of liking this anime. The other characters are nothing special, and he gets the vast majority of the attention in terms of character development and close shots. 
He is definitely not for everyone. Cold, unemotional, overpowered, he often seeks like he is just going through the motions of life, not really engaging in anything.
What did I like? His lazer like focus ona single person was captivating. He didn't care if the world burned, he didn't care if people hated him. But he did care because if the world hated him, then that would reflect badly on his sister. 

In terms of overpowered, I don't think that it is as bad as other reviewers make it out to be. Most of the action here is him dealing with the limitations that are imposed on him, and overcoming those limitations, or breaking them. His greatest weakness is being unable to connect with the emotions of people around him, and one of the larger plot threads is how he manages to gain the trust of those people even though he has no feelings for them, which is about as impressive to me as it sounds. 

There is one more thing I like about this character which is more personal. I go to an elite liberal arts college, and try to find the very best and brightest there and surround myself with them. And so I am friends with some amazing people. I know people who just describing a list of their skills would be considered bragging, and so they intentionally hide their skills so that others don't feel inferior. I know people who care little about anything other than success and are willing to do anything to find that success. People who I have seen almost no emotion from whatsoever after years of interacting with them. So to me, Shiba is not this weird alien character, but in fact, a representation of these overachievers I know and love. 



2. The technobabble: As this is a novel adaptation, there is an awful lot of technobabble. The characters spend about as much time talking about their magic as they do using it. Now, to me this is pretty great. After all, I am a computer programmer who likes discussing technical stuff. And it is decently well done, as good as I could have hoped for in an anime. But it really does take an awful lot of time, and is not fun to look at. 


3. The incestuous implications. The brother-sister relationship is much stronger than most, which I found fascinating and compelling, and crucial to the plot. But others might find it disturbing.


Now,


Just taking into consideration the above combined with the superb animation, etc, this could have a 9. But there were some serious flaws that I found lacking.


What did I find lacking?


1. The 9 schools tournament story drags on forever (11 episodes). From a story perspective, it seemed to me that it is a slow reveal to all the other characters that Shiba is amazing. They tried to show how Shiba and his sister's overpowering skills hurts some of the  people around him, perhaps exposing flaws? I didn't really get why this was so important. It takes nearly half of the anime, and since Shiba is my favorite character, and he has little development in this section, I was pretty bored. 


2. No backstory worth mentioning. I love backstories, and Shiba's was super incomplete.


3. Side characters are not all that great. The only characters with any development or backstory are the ones who side with the bad guys. The other side characters are totally flat, and there are way too many of them.

Magic has become a part of technology and is hence taught as a type of technical skill. First High School divides their students into two types which they call "Blooms" (the "express course") and "Weeds" (the "normal course"). The show follows the Shiba siblings, Tatsuya (or Godsuya as I like to call him) and Miyuki.
The show was off to a fair start imo, but as it progressed, I saw no clear plot. Fights were all right, but they could have been much better. Especially the fight between Tatsuya and the one who could potentially be his toughest opponent in the show, which for me, lackeda lot of intensity and served as a major turnoff. There's also Miyuki, who can be really annoying with her constant "onii-sama"-ing and her seemingly incestuous dialogue. Music was all right. I personally liked the second ending theme, Mirror by Rei Yasuda.


I think this show would appeal to people who would like an OP MC, some futuristic magic stuff and a little pinch of incest. Nothing actually happened though, just Miyuki's potentially incestuous and slightly cringy dialogue.

I first got interested in this anime after I heard from several forums, reviews, and anime sites that Tatsuya was an exceptionally cool character and fell into one of the genres I liked.  After seeing this anime in it's entirety many times, I can say he is a very cool character.  The show hits upon many genres and does so seamlessly and very well.  The story is enrapturing without falling into the tired BS so commonly associated with Anime in general like the dozens of cliches and reused character templates.  It has great characters and though the author himself denies it,half the cast appears to have some form of Autism.  So maybe he created characters with Autism without realizing it but they pass muster for strong qualities befitting of the condition.  That is actually one of the reasons it is such a great show.  It is one of the few if not only times, Autism is not shown as a strictly negative condition but is shown in a strongly much more positive light than any other story, movie, or tv show I have ever experienced.  Wether they actually have it or not as the author claims they do not is irrelevant.  At the very least, they are characters people with Autism can very strongly identify with.  The explanations of magic are rather convoluted and sloppy and the strong hint of the bro-con sister gets a bit dull.  In fact, Miyuki is probably the worst and most annoying character in the show and the biggest drawback.  If the author were to ever somehow make them end up together it might well ruin the story completely, but thankfully so far that has not happened and hopefully it won't.  Aside from those few negative issues, the show is addictive to watch.  If you were into spies you would love all the secrets, undercover work, and hidden conflicts going on under the surface.  It has magic, hidden powers, high school, drama, espionage, war, mechas, and hints of love.  


Tatsuya is not omnipotent nor OP as many others would have you believe nor is he 'emotionless'.  His lack of emotion is an illusion.  If you read the novels especially, you will know he is more than capable of emotional outbursts that have nothing to do with his sister as the show claims the only emotion he has left is his sibling love for her.  The series and novels suggest several characters who can or have defeated him and several even Tatsuya is wear about if not fearful.  Mayumi is the perfect potential love interest even if Tatsuya doesn't know it.  She is without exception the best and probably most powerful of the main characters since Miyuki lacks much confidence anyway.  Erika is the next most significant character and one of the main sources of humor and social interaction among the group of friends.  Leo is probably the closest thing to a best friend and the first male friend his age Tatsuya makes.  Mizuki is not much different personality wise than Miyuki but a much better, more solid, and more stable character.  Miki is almost a male version but is still a better character who gradually develops some confidence in part to support the more meek Mizuki.


Like many anime some important scenes are skipped or sped through so viewers may miss a few points but sadly this is very common in virtually all anime ever made.  This is an excellent hidden power show as several characters either hide from others, hide their powers, or hide their full or true abilities or even hide their identities.  There are many good 'ah-ha' moments, where your excitement is stirred by something incredible.  The last episodes has some of the best season ending moments ever.  The beginning maybe a bit slow but it does establish who is what pretty well such as when Mayumi is the first and only female who ever treats Tatsuya like a human and an equal from the get go.  (No his sister does not qualify, though it does not show it in the anime, it does have subtle hints, but until just a few years prior, Miyuki treated him like a worthless object so she doesn't get to claim true love even if she wasn't his sister).  Leo is the first guy to do that so, he belongs as his first and best friend.


This is a solid entertaining and enjoyable anime with a compelling and deep story filled with action, drama, humor, martial arts, and fascinating displays of magical powers.  What it gets right it gets very right: great action; martial arts mixed with magic; modern and ancient magic classifications; characters (except Miyuki); opening and closing songs (filler songs get repeated and tiring though); aha moments; use of magic; hidden powers angle; character development; the freshman monolith code event; and use of awesome powers near the end.  Only a few things prevent me from giving it a perfect ten and that is: Miyuki both her bro-con obsession and her subpar character; the show ended too soon and needs more episodes; long winded explanations of magical power and engineering; skipping on key components and backgrounds from the novels; and a few cheesy scenes like the ones between Mizuki and Mikihiko before the thesis competition.

To put it bluntly, the anime suffers from terrible characters, which impact the story severely to the point it's... not unwatchable, but you gain nothing at it and get really annoyed as to why you wasted your time after you finished the anime.
As a main character, Shiba Tatsuya is boring to hell. He does not emote, or show any emotion whatsoever. There's an explanation as to why he  does this, but you don't find out until the end, hell I'm not even sure that I figured out in the anime, I think i had to read the manga to get the full explanation.
His abilitiesalso rob the series of any conflict or challenge whatsoever because within the middle of the anime, I figured out that basically he'll pull some technobabble out of his pants and own the competition no matter how hard they tried. I hate to spoil, but the thing is... Tatsuya's disability isn't actually a disability. It's one of those blatantly stupid "he's too powerful to do simple stuff, he has to use nuke powers and nothing else". 


Combined with Tatsuya's bland character, the abilities he has writes out any meaningful conflict within the series. The series tries to say he struggles to do what he does, but he doesn't emote, so he never shows it. 


This is not to say non-emotional characters are boring, but they need to be written better so that their lack of an emotion is an interesting conflict. Unfortunately, the Irregular at Magic High School has people throwing themselves in praise of Tatsuya despite the fact that... he's got the emotions of a robot, and is a bit of an arrogant jerk to boot.


The problems with Tatsuya as the main character extend to the rest of the cast, who embody basic anime cliches to the point that I sometimes find it difficult to differentiate the male members of the cast from one another as they often embody the same "comrade/buddy" cliche. His sister's characterization is even worse as she's portrayed as an emotional woobie, but a magical powerhouse... which would be interesting if she actually faced any kind of meaningful conflict her brother wouldn't just solve in two seconds.


These poorly written characters thus really don't do well for the story, which can't give a conflict that Tatsuya and his band of overpowered, bland, ensemble cast members can't solve without too much difficulty.  Thus the story... suffers.


To make matters worse, while the art is pretty good, the actions scenes... are not well-designed. The magic system they use is a technobabble system that relies on strategy/cunning rather than simple brute force.  But... it's so technobabble heavy nobody can understand whats happening and so it instead becomes an excuse for Tatsuya to make stuff up and own everybody. And yet, one can't get a good sense of how crazy this is because the system itself isn't really flashy, so no tension or sense of fulfilment is built up.


At their worst, fight scenes thus devolve into, who can spew more technobabble.  At their best, they're...people hitting each other with special swords or shooting each other with guns. Not particularly fun for a Shounen anime.

Irregular at Magic Highschool is probably the most infuriatingly incompetent anime I have ever had the displeasure of witnessing. Do not watch this. Just save yourself the pain and don't. Writing, story, characters, plot, animation, sound, every single part of this anime is mediocre to average, barely scraping an acceptable pass or failing entirely due to its sheer lack of trying.
Pretty much all that happens in the story is this, but three times: Some random terrorist organization with no clear or sensible motive but is set up as bad because they want to shoot people or whatever makes a stupid move to piss off themain character, main character strolls in and kills or captures everyone without any difficulties because he is a god, end plot arc. Riveting stuff, truly. Not even kidding, this same plot happens *three times*, just in slightly different ways. And yet, the presentation of this story somehow still manages to be janky and weird even with how basic it is. I often found myself confused as to why I was even being shown stuff. Many scenes could simply be removed and nothing would change, due to being completely pointless or introduced in such a confusing way or way too early so that you forget about them by the time they are relevant. If the story wasn't already lacking anything compelling, the writing is something a tenth grader could write, causing actions that are meant to make me care more about the story or characters to fall completely flat.


Well, what if you want to watch for the characters? It's simple really, don't. Almost all of the characters, dare I say maybe even every single one, are forgettable and bland basic characters that have been boiled down to one or two simple personality traits, along with no character development throughout the entire runtime. None of the characters changed from episode one to the last episode in any meaningful way, they're all exactly the same. This is partly due to trying to handle too many characters, many got barely any screen time to the point where you almost forget they exist. The main character is the worst of them all, the writers were clearly trying *so god damn hard* to make him the most badass character ever, giving him way too many abilities, taking away his emotions so he seems cooler, and writing in a bunch of cheesy lines.


Interested in the lore and universe? Don't watch for that either. The backstory makes barely any sense when scrutinized, as no explanation is given for any of the presented history and it doesn't hold up much to common sense. The world is pretty much just modern day, even though it's eighty years in the future with magicians, plenty of what is shown could be made today or *is* made today, this problem being especially prevalent in the beginning of the anime. But don't even get me started on the magic system itself. Every time they introduce a new spell or element they try and explain how it works, great right? Except every single explanation in this godforsaken anime is a bunch of technobabble nonsense using made up words that are never clearly defined. It took me approximately fifteen episodes to even have an elementary grasp of the simplest and most vital of the terms they use to explain every other phenomenon. Even then it's only a rudimentary understanding that still leaves you with no actual comprehension if you stop for even two seconds to try and figure out how any of this magic actually works. This is a huge over-arching theme with the explanations in Irregular at Magic, is that every single one is missing some huge key point that fits it all together, but without this piece, it all is just nonsense babbling filling the time slot. This is never fixed in any of the twenty-six episodes.


Another huge problem is how there is never any tension in the plot, as every situation is dealt with by some new ability of the main character that we haven't seen until now. And every time it happens, every other character is shocked because it is some top secret military tech or some new tech created by the main character. They then give one of those infamous technobabble explanations that don't really help you understand anything at all then move on. What makes the lack of tension or stakes even worse is that the enemies they face are almost all idiots, especially in the first half of the anime. Anyone who is not on the side of the main cast instantly loses about fifty IQ points. As well as that, anything that is thrown at the main cast is handled with extreme ease. Guns, mechs, tanks, bombs, everything is dealt with as if it was a marble thrown by a toddler. What is even worse is that by the ending episodes it has devolved to the point where even if a character were to die it isn't a big deal because we can literally just regenerate them instantly. Where are the stakes at that point? The most egregious part, and I cannot stress this enough, is how over-powered the main character is. He has so much power he is on the level of a god. The only thing that *might* stop the main character is fifty nukes all aimed at him. But even then it's not a guarantee. What do you even do when your character is so powerful that there is not a single scenario I can foresee where he would ever be defeated? There are simply no stakes at all by the time you know the full extent of his powers. Even before he starts using the full extent, he can still bring down almost anyone he wishes while barely trying.


On top of all the other terrible factors, the animation is simple and basic, the absolute minimum that is acceptable to look at all decent. It only barely scrapes by as looking okay, with the barest of movements for characters to look alive, even at the peak moments of the story. They also made the terrible decision to employ 3D CG throughout some of the more difficult scenes, and while I can handle a little use of 3D in the right places, they go overboard here. There is some truly terrible CG, but the true sin is how they went and used it for a major portion of the final few episodes, making what I assume are meant to be formidable mechs and interesting fight scenes look laughable.


Audio work is also barely passable. The opening is extremely average and nothing new or special at all, and the background music often just sounds like a bunch of crap being mashed together. Need it to sound techy? Add in a bunch of annoying computer-sounding bleeps. Sports event? Add in some whistles or something who cares even at this point. There was never once a piece of music or sound work that actually stood out at all. It was all just passing.


The entirety of Irregular at Magic Highschool is the definition of aiming for a passing grade and not going any further. If you stripped the entire anime down to the most bare-bones form, then fleshed it out with good content, it would be fine. But that isn't saying much as instead, we are dealing with this trash heap. Everything combines to create a boring, generic, brainless piece of nonsense. There is not a single thing I can find to praise. Save yourself the time, and watch something better.

Bro and Sis? Sis has a brother con? She scares all other women away? Is this Oreimo in disguise?
No, not really. Instantly we're thrown into the school where the elite are separated from the weak or so they think.
Tatsuya Shiba, one of the most classiest anime characters I have ever seen is the brother of ace Miyuki Shiba and she is quite fond of her bro.
Moving along without spoiling anything, as the series progresses, you see the development of the cast and especially how cool Tatsuya is, umm have I mentioned how cool he is?
Anyways, despite appearances, Tatsuya has a pseudo-harem building around him andI'm really looking forward to the movie coming this summer.

in brief : if you liked 'gakusen toshi asterisk' and 'le fruit de la grisaille', you'll probably like this one ; there are flavours of both here.
i started out the series rolling my eyes with a sigh, thinking, 'well, the gang's all here : the meganekko, the kuudere, the cutie with a brocon, the kendo girl, the flustered loli with annoying falsetto, etc.  however, i was quickly drawn in to the story and found myself rooting for them despite their stereotypes.
unlike many harem and quasi-harem shounen anime, the mc here isn't a wimp. in fact he's smart, full of aplomb, and totally badass !for most of the series, it was fun watching him [and, incidentally, the others too] deal with the unfolding surprises [of which there were many] and kick the crap out of his opponents. on the other hand, in my opinion he might be TOO badass ; i stopped worrying about the characters as the series developed because i knew, whatever happened, 'eh, the mc will sort it out like he always does', so dramatic tension actually lessened as the series continued.\n\n
to be clear, this series isn't really harem, even though it does have tendencies in that direction.  there were many interesting side characters, both male and female, and they were developed enough to pique my interest.  even so, i wanted more.  i felt they could have been given real depth if only the writers had dedicated a little more time to them.\n\n
there are also quite a few of the usual cliché situations, but finally, they didn't detract all that much.  the action sequences were exciting and fun, the effects were really well drawn, and the plot [yes, there's an actual plot!] was interesting.

Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei. High school? Check. Super powers? Check. Overpowered main character? Check. Enjoyable? Hell yeah!
The story of this one is fairly basic and you will see many copies of this one in other anime. I personally really enjoy an overpowered main character, it's one of my sweet spots I suppose. 
The art is impressive and really compliments the fight scenes, although I found the music to be fairly forgettable, with an exception for the opening, which was amazing.
The characters in general are executed well, although they are not by all means really interesting. It's about what you would expect in an anime likethis, nothing new, nothing special.\n\n
This however did not detract from my enjoyment, which I suppose is entirely subjective. I don't really know what it is that I find so particularly satisfying about a main character being underestimated again and again, just to destroy his 'enemies' a few minutes later.\n\n
If you enjoy these types of anime and you are like me, definitely give this one a shot, you will not regret it. If you're looking for an interesting story and good character development, I'd advise skipping this one, it won't be your cup of tea.

The main character, Tatsuya, goes to school with his sister. This school has a system where there are course 1 and 2 students. Course 2 students, known as weeds, are the underperforming magic students. And Course 1 students, known as Blooms, are the overperforming magic students. 
The story was good. It had interesting aspects that a lot of magic anime don't really have, such as the whole CAD thing, which makes casting spells faster and more efficient. The master clans was cool, I just wish they went deeper into it, because all they mentioned was that there were these clans which were run by differentfamilies. That's it. That's all there was. It sounded like a good start, but there wasn't much else about the clans. Magic is a favorite theme in anime. I love these types of things, since they don't happen in real life. The school system was a cool feature, but there were a lot of things that didn't stick in the overall plot, and were just there to serve one task, then were forgotten. Which was a little sad, but it happens all the time in short anime series, so I'll let it slide. Overall, the story was pretty cool.


I wont go into art and sound, beyond the fact that they did it really well. I loved the colors, although it was overdone sometimes.


The characters were Mediocre at best. There was a loli, a sister with a brother-complex and a brother with a sister-complex, A flirty manipulator who may or may not be the student council president, a loud mouthed girl with wild hair who is friends with a quiet girl, two quiet girls one who is most likely in love with the main character but too afraid to say anything and the other who is there to support the other quiet one, and lastly, to finish my point, a big guy who can be nervous, but stands up for others.


I did enjoy it, besides all it's flaws. It is an enjoyable show, mostly later on in the series, but if you enjoy school anime, you'll like this anime early on. It does have a softcore incest type thing going on, but not quite fullblown incest. So you've been warned if you don't like that type of thing. The incest starts loud, then calms down, then gets out of control near the end.


Well... I don't really know what else to say. I just finished the anime, and the ending was extremely disappointing. I won't say anything beyond that.

When I first saw this series, it peeked my interest, however I didn't get around to watching it for several months. A time came around when I had little on my agenda to watch, and so something brought me back to this anime, and I'm quite glad that it did. 
As the anime progressed, I found that the more episodes I watched, the more interested in it I became. Seeing as how there are three main story arcs in this short anime, I would say that they get better and better. The first story arc was a little dull for my own taste and theaction only came in closer to the end. The second one got a little more interesting, and the third finally gave us that battle/war story line that had been hinted at during the previous episodes. 


There are several reasons that this anime may be a turn off for some people, such as the very VERY strong and slightly uncomfortable relationship between the main siblings, the very quick escalation of sometimes rather grotesque violence, and the fact that there is little character development. However, the violence is in no way bad enough to be considered a horror/gore anime and let's be honest, many great anime do have that unusual sibling bond. As for the lack of character development in the main character, that is something which the audience just has to be fine with in order to fully appreciate this short anime for what it is.


One point of this anime I was satisfied with was the characters. Even though the number of important characters increased during the second story arc, each character had a unique personality to them (for the most part as far as the important characters go) that added to the story. Another aspect of this anime I enjoyed was the overall concept. The way that it was set in the future and used a combination of sci-fi/mecha with fantasy/magic was rather pleasing for me, seeing as how I have a hard time watching straight up mecha anime; they managed to combine the two in a successful way that made sense and didn't get too jumbled together. 


The biggest downfall to this anime was the shortness of it. Unfortunately, shorter, more rushed anime are what is to be expected these days I find. When it ended, I found myself wishing that there had been more to it as I was still left with a number of unanswered questions. Watching the final arc, I found myself eager to get to the next episode, hoping for answers or further character development on some of the newly introduced characters, but found myself rather disappointed when the final episode came to a close and I had many questions still. The story to this anime had major potential had it gone further to touch on more aspects in further detail which makes me wonder about how much further the story went in the manga.

First of all before the review I would like to inform the two groups that (IN MY OPINION) watch this anime. 
1. I completely agree that this anime is definitely not for everyone and that this anime would have converging sides based on the persons interest as well as what they perceive the character to be.
2. This leads to the two groups. People who actually really love this anime and would recommend it 10/10 and the people who may actually dislike the story due to a 'wasted' plot or just in there opinion.
I however, am siding with the recommend side of this anime as Ihad so much fun watching it. In my opinion this story is great if you're looking for this total badass character who literally gives no S@!?. This perhaps may put people off due to this guy literally not losing, but I guess that this is why I like the character so much. I don't know why but I think this character is really likeable, has other great mains and secondary, which people may argue unnecessary, but I still like watching their interesting backstories as well as their development.\n\n
Without further elaborating, my second point is that the merging of science, technology and magic creates a great story. I think they can expand to zero limitations of their imaginations as well as the powers of every individual and the increasing plot and story lines. However, due to such a great explanation and foundation people may see it as a 'wasted' plot centred around a character who seems to have it all. But further on I still think this can be increased.\n\n
Overall, to summarise I really enjoy this anime and for anybody who is looking for an entertaining anime to watch should definitely consider Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei. Thank you!\n\n
-JanZPH

Story: The story is about a high school that hard to get into. You have to have some ability to get in. The anime shows that the school also has a segregation issue. The people that have high magic known as course 1 students or blooms and the other group with low magic or some other ability is course 2 also known as weeds. The vibe of the high school is blooms are better and should not be seen talking to a weed. The magic system in this anime works like a hash table. There a particular sequence of number that you would into adevice and that launches a magical attack. A person knowning what magical attack you are doing is konwn to be impossible (well except for the one character)


The focus is on two siblings. One is the younger sister. Who has lot of magical potential and since she was the best from teh entrance exam she gave the speech. She was placed in the bloom. The other person who did not do so well in the magical exam is a weed the older brother. The younger sister respect the older brother a lot. She knows that her brother is much better than any exam. His knowledge of magic is unmatched and how his magic is different from everyone elses. He also can read and know what magical attack you are going to do. Not only that but the brother is also super strong and agile. All of these make him irregular. SO the story follow these two going throug the magical school.


Rating time:


Plot: This is interesting. The plot overall seem fine. You have a powerful character and you see that he is fighting towards a goal. The problem may be fixed with additional seasons, but as it currently stand there is a lot of holes in the anime. Like why are they put in this situatin, why are they like this. Why is he like that. Whose that. There a lot of questions. Secondly, there a lot of explanation. Like lots of it, there over explaning every little thing sometimes. The action part of the anime is great, but there less action and more talking it seem like, and I like talking anime but this one kinda took a point and kept talking about it and it like I get it. Please move on lol. I give this a 7/10


Animation: I think the animation of this anime is great. They quality seem like today type of anime. And it not even a ecchi anime lol. I give it a 9/10


Sound: I watch this anime in japanese dub. The voice acting was fine, I had no issue with it. The music and background music. I was fine with some and was like what for others lol. I would give this a 6.5/10 


Characters: Introduction to characters were great. Character evolving, well the main character didn't really have a progression, it was mostly the surrounding cast that were accepting but that about it.The character past was done poorly, but maybe because they needed more seasons. Based on the information I have I would give this a 6.5/10


Overall with bias: It wasn't a bad anime, it was a lot of explaining and you can get tired of this. I enjoy the fight scenes or scenes when they weren't explaining things. I think I would give this anime a 7/10. It might  be better in future season though.


Recommendation: Hard to say. If you like the idea then you might like it and would recommend as long as you know there are lot of explanation going on in the anime.

Disclaimer: This is a simple review of the anime with overall comments from me and mine alone, please take this review as a grain of salt as I have not read any books about this (LN or Manga)
The Story itself, IF you've watched the Grisaia series it's pretty much like this, Cold as Ice MC with no emotion regarding about anything to faze him, but the difference between the two anime series is that in this series the MC is portrayed as normal with basic human courtesy and decency to the opposite sex, unlike in the Grisaia series.
I've been comparing this to the Grisaia seriesbut this is actually about 70% Grisaia in way but that's about it.


Sound wise, many high pitch noises are going in your ear all the time since the theme of the series is about Futuristic Magic about sequence and coding, I have to lower the volume sometimes even if I'm not using my headset at all times.


Art, I want to basically compare this to the Grisaia series alot since it's basically it, but with magic! except Grisaia has special episodes bundled ...


Character Development, Pretty much not normal, I get the fact the sister is a hard on Bro-con and all but that's it, no back story about the MC just a few sequence of sepia animation about war and such, why does the MC treated that way (apart from the School Discrimination part)


Enjoyment, sometimes anti-climactic, the MC is overpowered in a way but not too overpowered if you put it in a basic way, He's mainly above any others except his superiors.


Overall, decent, above average story with a some back stories, but not with the MC, i don't think it's rushed story wise but it's decent.


7/10 : will recommend.
